pr_title: [windows][melodic] Fix ambiguous call for tf2::convert on MSVC
pr_contents: This is another attempt to rework -
. Here is the previous attempt
When building a downstream project (MoveIt), it fails to compile and reports

For MSVC, it requires to be explicit on what's the namespace of the overloaded templated (and non-templated functions). On the flip side, for GCC\Clang, specifying the namespace requires the overloaded functions to be forward-declared and which would mean to shuffle the header inclusion by different order.
Making all the overloaded functions visible before
gets defined looks to me a more proper fix. However, given
is a

in ROS stack, I am hesitate to do much extensive header refactoring. So I am simply using compiler conditional guard to mitigate the build break (and added a test case to synthesize the MoveIt usage).
Hi! I am trying to rework the ambiguous call problem for
in MSVC. Can you try to see if this patch passes the
build?
The CI fails at
step: Is it an known issue for now?
Can you try to see if this patch passes the clang build?
I guess you are referring to the MoveIt CI builds?
I guess you are referring to the MoveIt CI builds?
Yes! I am trying to tackle this issue here:
Unfortunately, I don't have time to look into this right now.
However, you could do it yourself: just prepare a PR against MoveIt, adding your tf2 repo to the
file. Travis should compile with your branch then. You can easily retrigger Travis by closing and reopening the PR. Please mark the PR as WIP, to emphasize that it is not intended for merging.
Thanks for tackling the problem!
Unfortunately, I don't have time to look into this right now.
However, you could do it yourself: just prepare a PR against MoveIt, adding your tf2 repo to the
file. Travis should compile with your branch then. You can easily retrigger Travis by closing and reopening the PR. Please mark the PR as WIP, to emphasize that it is not intended for merging.
Thanks for tackling the problem!
No problem! I will be trying the MoveIt Travis build.
Hey, nice to know that somebody else is tackling this issue
I made a proposal in
which is backward-incompatible but independent of the header include order.
To fix this in melodic, we could try to get rid of the templated forward-declarations of
and
in
. Then,
hopefully picks the correct (non-templated) overloads instead of the forward declaration. Note that AFAIK in this case all overloads have to be declared before
is used.
What about an explicit conversion in wrap_python_move_group.cpp?
This is of course only a workaround for the MSVC error message...
I would prefer, if you can come up with a solution that doesn't require to modify downstream projects.
MoveIt is for sure only one out of many projects utilizing tf conversions.
This is ready for review and merge. I verified the change with the MoveIt CI too and it shows all green:
The fix is probably not the optimal, but I think it comes with a very low risk to break the downstream project, especially for
release.
Thank you for your effort, but IMHO the issue is still not solved in general. To make this clear:
When you try to compile this with gcc 7.4, gcc 9.2 or clang 9 this results in a linker error:
It somehow compiles fine with MSVC (tested on godbolt). If you uncomment the
statement, it compiles fine with gcc and clang.
TL; DR As I explained in
are not template specializations (indicated with
) but traditional overloads. So either the forward declaration have to be removed (in convert.h) or all overloads have to become a template specialization (which breaks current downstream projects)
Friendly ping.

pr_title: Added recover and stop in RobotHW
pr_contents: Proposal for extension of RobotHW with recover and stop functions for easier hardware management. See code comments for explanation of this functions. Hope this can be also useful for many other robots, since we are using it with Schunk modules/robots and rob@work mobile robot.
I'm in favour of this— particularly when using combined_robot_hw, it would be nice to have a way to notify all RobotHW plugins to stop or start up again based on some external system state.
Should there be something added to ControllerManager to actually call the stop function on shutdown, since the comment hints that that will occur?
Could you please add a test that could double as a reference implementation for our documentation as well please?
Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
I am not sure about this..
In which case should these functions get called and by which part of the chain?
I can see
' point with combined_robot_hw, but this PR does not address this fully.
IMHO we need interfaces in the other direction, to notify that some joints are not active anymore.
Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
rob@work is the industrial version of Care-O-bot, almost all  of the (original) drivers are public.
: Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware
controller manager code.
For the example of the generic controller manager see under.
: Would something like this be suitable as test?

: one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware the same controller manager code.
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..
I have just noticed that RobotHW got
and
functions
IMHO these should have been added to a derived, but abstract
class.
Now we can combine any RobotHW, but cannot run it, because not all classes actually implement these functions.
Originally,
was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.

one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Our department switched to
, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed
in the first place..
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..

Yes. What I meant is that is reused on multiple hardware. Currently for most of the RobotHW implementation there is also CM implementation to start the node (it is not wrong, but not efficient for managing 5+ robots)
Originally, RobotHW was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.
OK, but how should be than responsible for hardware initialization and stopping? In current implementation for initialization is CM but not for stopping. IMHO we can put it in RobotHW interface...
Our department switched to ros_canopen, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed std_srvs/Trigger in the first place..
I know. I am also using your repositories  on daily basis :) Actually this was also inspired with your CM implementation in
. the problem came when we added other Schunk hardware (not canopen capable) in ros_control (pw70 and SDH). I can also share my code, but currently depends on our internal ros_control extension :)
This would be really useful - I would strongly vote for this to be merged! I would also propose to add this functionality to the CombinedRobotHW class
I am very interested in having such methods in the hardware interface for a simple robot (
) or a composed one (
, which is lacking in this pull request).

In our case, we want to implement a wireless soft emergency stop for our battery-operated robots. This seems to be the best place to stop and restart the robots. On the restart, we would then have the controller manager's
method be called with the
option enabled.
We had considered the option of switching controllers, but this seems to be an other possible point of failure in the system, which we would like to avoid.
Hi all,
we updated our branch to be compatible with combined_robot_hw. Is this no OK?
This applies here as well:
pr_quotes: Also, if the rob@work drivers are public that'd be a nice addition :)
Regarding ControllerManager we have our own generic implementation of ControllerManager since I was annoyed to write for every hardware the same controller manager code.

one of the main reasons to implement this is actually better support for hardware drivers provided by your department (e.g. rob@work, schunk_modular_robotics). Without this on any error, or after Emergency-Stop you can only restart the component completely...
Your code uses the standard ControllerManager..
Originally, RobotHW was meant to provide state/command access to controllers, but not to grant full, exclusive control over the hardware.
Our department switched to ros_canopen, which already implements this (init, halt, recover, shutdown services) ;)
That's one of the reasons we proposed std_srvs/Trigger in the first place..

pr_title: Add DowngradeAnalyser for reporting non-critical errors
pr_contents: Our robots react on the top-level state of the aggregator. But sometimes we have error which are relevant to know, but not critical at all for operation.
Therefor the DowngradeAnalyser, still report but just be happy.

Looks reasonable to me. Something similar we've experimented with is a folding analyzer— if error X is set, downgrade errors Y and Z, so that there isn't user confusion about which problem to resolve first.

Obviously the whole business of halting operation over diagnostics is in violation of the diagnostics REP, but it's a pretty common pattern, and awfully convenient given that there isn't any other commonly-supported system in ROS for exposing machine consumable component-level status:
I get the concerns indicated in the REP.
But doing it another way probably means implementing an pretty identical layout.

But regardless of that, we have a green/yellow/light on our robot which indicates the diagnostics status. If this is red because of known issues, users will become insensible for the red light and the whole idea is gone.
Does this PR need any more work to get accepted?
It looks good to me, but I'm not the maintainer of this repo, just an interested third party.
what do you think of this DowngradeAnalyser next to the DiscardAnalyser?
Added rules to copy files necessary for running the module with "make install".
I need to put the module in a Docker container and therefore determine the files that need to be copied.

and also make sure that all CI tests are green?

and copied the relevant directories to a docker container, the program failed to launch, complaining that it can't load
, which is obviously false, because the parrot_arsdk package was installed with apt-get.

from
to
in my container. When the symlinks are in
it can find the libraries.
I am not experienced with ROS library discovery mechanism to know why that is.

The problem might be on my side since the install rules for
(as you correctly figured out) install the shared libraries into a sub-folder of
. The main rationale behind that decision was not to pollute the default ROS libraries folder with custom
and
that is compiled as part of
. I will look into this issue more this weekend.
I think I've found a workaround for runtime discovery of
libraries:

does?

pr_contents: does anyone use power on/off?
is it possible to add your start/stop impedance button at here?
インピーダンスを入れるのに，limbの先端のjoint名が必要で，
それがロボットごとに違うので諦めるということが半年くらい前にありましたが，
最近のhrpsys-baseのインピーダンスに更新があって
今ならlimb名だけでインピーダンスをstart/stopできるようになっていたりしますでしょうか？
さん
を見ると力センサ名だけが必要になったようです．
HRP2の手先センサ名は lhsensor, rhsensor となっていて，
色んなロボットでこれが同じであればすんなりできそうです．
違う場合はどうするのがいいでしょう．
（STAROはlasensor, rasensorみたいになっていて，HRP2とは違った気がしています．）
遅くなりました。
引数は今いくつか整理しつつあって、わりと最後の悩みポイントが
とするか
とするか、でした。
ImpedanceControllerの内部では力センサと1対1にデータポートがついて、ImpedanceParamも使える状況になってます。
基本的には後者の"rarm"などがロボットの差異もなくて良いと思いましたが、
後者だと同じrarmないに複数センサがある場合に使い分けられないとおもい、どうしようかと思いました。
ただ、やはり同じrarmに複数センサがある状況はなしと考えて良いきがしてきたので、
にしようと思います。
にも関係しますが、もし複数のhrpsys-baseのバージョンで動かすのであれば
のようなstartImpedance的な関数をhrpsys_config.pyに追加して、
としておいて、dashboardからはstartImpedanceとだけ呼べばどちらも動くように思います。

pr_contents: This could just as well apply to
but we have only tested with
at the moment.
This is the distillation of
to a pull request that has been tested on a robot with 3 sensors. Much of the initial development was done by
, with design refinements and bugfixes added.
Many of the changes (ie,
) were written to support the "simple" default clearer, which should be
the same as the original (current) implementation. Now, using a parameter flag (
), the new algorithm can be applied instead, which creates a volumetric cache around each clearing sensor to apply to the costmap.
The cache is used to speed up the implementation, and should have larger impact with more points to clear. We profiled the initial implementation, shown
, but have not profiled the latest code. However, we have used it in practice on a live robot and there are no qualitative speed issues.

One overall issue with such a commit such as this is that there is currently no simple way to perform unit/integration tests to establish its correctness (this applies to many components of the nav stack). One suggestion would agree upon a test bagfile, as well as test launch and parameter files, so that all components of the execution could be properly controlled. This seems like a larger issue that would need more work/consensus, but I think it would be worth the effort.
I know this is a large change but I encourage testing and consideration into the main branches.
Heya,

During some debugging of our robot that uses the Intel Realsense rgbd sensor I ran into an issue that I "think" is related to this PR. Our system seeminglyrefuses to clear a cell in the voxel costmap if the marked voxel is neighboring a cell in the "unknown" space. In the screenshot below the blue voxels are this "unknown area" and the red voxels are marked as obstacles. These were marked as I was entering or leaving the robot's field of view. Reading the attached issue it sounds like this is the so called "corner case" but I wanna confirm. Do you think my problem could be fixed with this PR? Thanks :)
Yes, sounds exactly like what this should be solving.
Okay cool. We will test this out some time in the next week and post back :)
Just a heads up

that this PR should work in practice but is currently failing a test due to some refactoring that wasn't retroactively applied to the test, so only use this as a temporary fix. I will update the PR so that it passes tests shortly.

, this never made it to the official release? I am facing the "clear corner case" again, with an Orbbec Astra this time (I am also using an RPLIDAR laser as a second observation source without issues).
I tested your commit

and noticed a clear computation performance drop. My local map cannot keep the update rate at 5Hz, and my control loop also fails to send cmd_vels to the base at 10Hz. As expected, the clearance issues and ghost pixels seem to go away.

I have not updated my original PR yet, but I would be interested to hear more about the details of your setup. We are using reasonably powerful computing so might not have noticed as great a drop, but we are using a comparable sensor set.

I have recently been back at this and have (finally) produced an update that passes all tests and has been verified on a real system, though not with rigorous experiments. I also included new tests to verify that the corner clearing works and does not break existing functionality if turned off, which is the default.
Also,
is correct about a performance hit, which led us to downsample our dense point cloud sensor with a VoxelGrid nodelet (to 0.05m voxels), and to also limit the clearing range.
Try increasing the
via dynamic reconfigure or try the
option.
There are still limits to the the max accuracy though.
Maybe also take a look at the
talk from
as an alternative

pr_title: Fix missing trajectory segment bug, removed deprecated code
pr_contents: This has the fix created by
as discussed in
where he says:

I looked at the joint_trajectory_controller code and I found that the start time of the first trajectory segment is calculated using the previous period. This might cause that the start time of the first trajectory is later than the next sample time when the previous period is longer(even 1us) than the current period because of the jitter. And this leads to the above error.
I ran his fix overnight with continuous trajectory interruption and the error did not occur again.
I've also removed a code block that was intended to be removed in indigo, and I added a section for optionally measuring message latency in actionlib using compiler flags.
Thank you for your quick work.
I'm not sure that the threshold is reasonably small or it should be smaller. I chose period because I didn't want to include any extra magic parameter.
I'm not sure either, I just know it works for me :)
Hopefully
can weight in
we are so slow here... :)
Will you have some time to separate this PR into 2 and send it against kinetic-devel?
I would like to merge the deprecation one and we can discuss about the segment one.
I'm afraid I do not currently have any projects requiring ros_control and I am focusing my energy on MoveIt and my looming thesis defense. Feel free to take over these changes.

I finally found the hours needed to test this on Kinetic (tested all packages depending directly on dynamic reconfigure).

There are several packages failing, some are warranted failures but for some the check seems a bit too restrictive. For example the comparison is made regardless of the parameter type, for string for example it may not make sense to do a comparison (arguably it may not make much sense to give a range to a string parameter in the first place..).

Some packages seem to set out of range values purposefully, I guess it's to reflect the "uninitialized" state. Though to confirm I guess we should reach out to the maintainers of these packages to see if it's a valid assumption.

pr_quotes: great to hear. However the impact of this pr might be quite substantial and require work on "unknown buggy" packages/config files

For example the comparison is made regardless of the parameter type, for string for example it may not make sense to do a comparison (arguably it may not make much sense to give a range to a string parameter in the first place..).

pr_contents: Since hrpsys 315.4.0 with updated
, rtcd on QNX fails on NEXTAGE Open as follows.
with this PR hopefully fixes the issue.
Please review
Relevant PR
better to have backward compatibility
better to have backward compatibility
確認ですが，次のように理解しています．
上記の理解で正しいとすると，バージョン互換性を保つためのコードを加えるべきは，正論としては下流の hrpsys と思っています．
よくわかっていませんが，両者は密接な関係がある等の理由で，正論通りにはいかず，hrpiob 側に互換コードを入れるのがこの場合正しい，という状況でしょうか？

, and that was solved by placing the right library. So I think we don't need to worry about
error.
Switched back to
, one good news is that with the updated
, it seems to have successfully launched. So the code in this PR is hrpsys-backward compatible so far (haven't tested running client commands yet).
I've added a couple of commits, and now I'm able to build with
script that comes within
folder.
I noticed, however, that cmake failed to find
by
on my QNX I'm using. I have to look into this but will appreciate if anyone has some immdiate clues.

#!/bin/sh

export JSK_DIR=/opt/jsk
export LOG_DIR=/opt/jsk/var/log
export PATH=$JSK_DIR/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/nextage-open/lib:/opt/jsk/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/nextage-open/lib
#export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$JSK_DIR/share/nextage-open/lib:$JSK_DIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/jsk/share/nextage-open
export RTCD_KILLNAME=rtcd

OS=`uname`
if [ "$OS" = "Linux" ]; then
  KILLALL="/usr/bin/killall -q"
elif [ "$OS" = "QNX" ]; then
  # On QNX many libraries requreid for hiro-nxo are installed via pkgsrc, which goes into /usr/pkg.
  export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/pkg/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
  KILLALL=/bin/slay
fi

#
# loop for rtcd
#
mkdir -p $LOG_DIR
$KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME

while :; do
    /opt/nextage-open/bin/unlock_iob

    if [ -f $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log ]; then
        rm $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    fi

    DATESTRING=`date +%Y%m%d%H%M%S`
    ln -s $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    rtcd -f /opt/jsk/etc/HIRONX/hrprtc/rtcdRobotMode.conf > $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log 2>&1

    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
done

pr_contents: Examples and interface for motion planning in C++ code using MoveIt.
May need to change
and
parameters to
in ompl_planning.yaml.
The coding follows kinetic version of MoveIt documents not the 2013 one.

Currently the interface does not allow setting goal_constraints with position and orientations (I have never gotten solutions within 10 minutes with this pattern). The interface calculates inverse kinematics and then calculates collision avoided paths between start joints and calculated goal joints (if the goal joints have collision, basically the planning will fail).

I have checked that the planning works with constraints (e.g. not changing the pose of the end effector). However, the planning is slow, it takes between 10 to 60 seconds to get a solution with constraints. The collision avoidance may give weird motion.
merge if seems okay. If not, please give reasons. Also please check if the samples run.
The sample shows an example of returning a motion trajectory that avoids hitting a container (the robot will hit the container if angles are sent directly without the motion plan)
We used move_group interface for using planning interface.
I think move_group is useful for handling collision objects.
You can launch aero_moveit_config/launch/real_robot.launch for testing move_group interface with rviz.
can you provide examples (similar to the ones pushed) in aero_samples using the move_group interface?

by the way, it seems there are two different types of interfaces. The move_group one communicates over a node, the one used in the pull request runs within C++ code. We could have both ways unless you insist there should only be one way of running codes to avoid confusion.
Anyway, I am wondering whether solving the pose goal will work with the node version.
updated comment. see on github
added some code related to
note, if anyone has trouble running code in kinetic with "RRTstar", this could be changed to "RRTConnect" (although RRTstar gives a better optimized trajectory).

Although there is already the moveit interface, the interface in this pull request allows more native control and access to the moveit functions.
There should be no problem with having such an interface, it's only an option and both ways of using moveit is official.
In other words, I'd like to have this merged. Thanks.

If you set a rough planning, the calculation becomes faster but the actual plan could have collision. Depending on the problem (or even machine power), it might be better to do a rough plan multiple times and find one solution without collision rather than waiting for one successful plan that takes time.
So I disagree with your comment.

Hi,
, I'd like to test this newly merged function of yours.
For this, I think I need bag files containing can_info (CAN messages).
I've recorded many bag files which normally include images (from a camera), pointcloud (with a LiDAR) and nmea sentences (by a GNSS); however, they've never had CAN messages yet.
I have my own test vehicle as large as ZMP RoboCar MV2, whose internal communications are all done via CAN.
Would you introduce how to record CAN messages (along with other signals from other sensors)?
FYI, I have the KVASER Leaf as a CAN interface.
Thank you for reading,
Hi,
You need to convert CAN messages to autoware_msgs::can_info by yourself. Autoware does not have any function for the converting.
If you successfully convert and publish them, you can record the can_info topic.
Thanks for your reply, @cirpue49 :)
In vehicle_receiver.cpp, can_info topic is being published -
ros::Publisher can_pub = nh.advertise<autoware_msgs::CanInfo>("can_info", 100);
It tells the ROS master that a message of type autoware_msgs\CanInfo is being published on the can_info topic.
This is followed by

Customized Autoware to work with a small autonomous mobile robot and participated on Tsukuba Challenge 2017, and add our branch here for other roboticists to use and for the general Autoware community as well.

Different from a vehicle, a robot is very dynamic and thus several modifications were necessary on the planner, specially obstacle avoidance. Several changes to launch files and new drivers are also included. Found and fixed some issues on NDT localization. Minor changes on runtime manager to support persistence and resizable dialogs. The default parameters match our running configuration.
There is a big issue we could not fix on NDT_mapping estimating the correct height of a map, other robot teams confirmed the same.
Outline the steps to test or reproduce the PR here.

Just run Autoware as always. Use the default parameters suit our robot needs but should be OK to fine tune things. The persistence on runtime manager will record some limited window state information to use at next run.

This is the map generated (red) of the Tsukuba Challenge environment, the official course (yellow), our best autonomous run of over 1km (green) and the official trajectory of our expected participation.
This is a picture of the robot used, it has a Velodyne VLP-16, Hokuyo UTM-30LX, SH2 motor control box, Grasshopper camera,
event camera (using
drivers), no GPS/GNSS/IMU (lidar based localization).
And here is OpenPlanner in action trying to avoid a large group of people.
Our rosbag and some maps and vector maps are stored on rosbag.tier4.jp (search for tsukuba)

pr_title: Fix for stuck in place rovers
pr_contents: Rovers would get stuck in the ROTATE state of the statemachine inside DriveController.cpp .  The values being passed out of the fastPID method were too low (varied from 40 all the way to 0 or 1).  The net result was the rover would send these through ROSAdapter into sendDriveCommand resulting in constant power to motors but the rover wouldn't move.  The fix was to set a hard min value for rover motor speeds coming out of fastPID inside the ROTATE state.  Currently set to 80 and seems to run ok.  Needs testing.  Made changes to PID.cpp and ROSAdapter.cpp with cleaning up and commenting all 3 files and moving some braces for readability while debugging problem.  Currently left debugging cout statements in code for future hardware testing.  Will remove once testing is complete before pull request is accepted.
Actual fix located in DriveController.cpp on lines 139-171
Fixes issue
1.) Rover no longer gets stuck while turning

pr_contents: This pull will add a motor step function in abridge. This causes the robot to change speed by a maximum value per frame. As speed changes are limited it is now difficult to ask for a speed change that would cause an over current event.

It may still be possible by taking a joystick and twirling it in a circle as fast as possible asking for rapid left right and forward reverse commands simultaneously. However this is a useless maneuver and thus is deliberately attempting to break the robot as this does not work in auto-mode.
Can you tell me what problems you've seen that this fixes?

Looking at your patches I see that you've limited the slew rate to 75 codes per frame and removed the maximum speed of 120 (now it seems to be back to 255). Do you have any data on the maximum slew rate?
please respond to
's question. Thanks.
First I found a bug that needs fixing before this can be accepted

Second, this fixes a problem where the robot rapidly commands a change in direction and this causes the motors to draw larger than normal amounts of current. As a result the self-resting fuse built into the PCB trips and cuts motor power essentially freezing a robot in place until motor commands stop long enough for it to cool down and reset.

Since auto runs at 10 frames per second this limits a -255 to 255 speed change to roughly 7 frames or 7/10ths of a second. However changes to a speed of 0 will be one frame as usually after I fix the bug
I will test it after the change is made. I should basically let it run for about 30 minutes and see if the rover freezes, correct?
, yes. Be sure to test the joystick control, keyboard control, and autonomous driving.

A major false assumption has been made that the UTM grid aligns with East and North, while it's not true.
For UTM projection (based on

) convergence (the angle between projected meridians and grid Y-axis) is zero on the equator and non-zero everywhere else. It increases as the poles are approached or as we're getting farther from central meridian.
In order to make our world frame aligned with ENU we need to account for this.
Otherwise, other ROS packages which rely on this property will misunderstand the orientation.
E.g.
which uses
gives tiles rotated about world frame origin without convergence adjusted.
This PR adds the needed correction. Meridian convergence is computed as in
which gives results very close to those used in UTM, based on

Thanks for the PR! I don't suppose you have a sample bag file or perhaps a visualization for this? I obviously see that this is a major fix, but for posterity, if we had a sample bag file or something to go with the PR, that would help.
Thanks again for taking the time to make this change.
Below snapshot from Rviz is shown with:
robot_localization - uses datum LatLon [50.4048, 30.5255] and world_frame "map",
Rviz - Fixed Frame is "map", Grid is for "map" frame, Axes show "map" frame origin,
rviz_satellite - shows 3x3 Google tiles around the datum at zoom level 20,

Green rectangle in Rviz is formed by specifying rectangular LatLon area corresponding to the 3x3 Google tiles with left bottom [50.4045789161, 30.5248260498] and right top [50.4052353746, 30.5258560181], converted to "utm" frame (zone 36) with
returns
At time 0.000
That is, zero magnetic declination and yaw offset are specified.

As you can see, Google tiles are aligned with the grid - because rviz_satellite assumes that "map" frame is ENU aligned. While green rectangle is rotated by some angle around "map" frame origin - because robot_localization uses LatLon -> utm conversion, hence points with equal longitude\latitude are converted to points with different utm_easting\northing, hence in "map" frame they also have different X\Y.
To solve this, we need "map" to be really ENU aligned - that is to be rotated by meridian convergence angle relative to "utm" frame.

Actually there was a bug in the outlier filter, but the newest commit should solve it:
The receive time (red) shows the effect of crony on the system clock (in which the receive time is measured).

The pre-filtered (green) is the outlier filter reacting before this commit. It basically explodes (goes off up to 2 minutes error in this example). With the fix, gray, it does exactly the bad thing one would expect in this case: ignores all further updates and yields a straight line.
The orange one shows nicely what is bad about a ConexHullFilter when clocks go crazy (without resetting).

The cyan is actually without any outlier filter. The other two are the newest Kalman and the ConvexHull filter but switching between two filters every 10 s and resetting the one that goes out of duty.
nice catch! I tested it again and everything works as expected when chrony is disable.

pr_contents: Please review,
Additional MCU msgs/srvs (to be documented on the jackal_firmware ROS wiki page):
nmea_msgs/Sentence -> raw strings to and from globaltop module
sensor_msgs/IMU -> raw data from accelerometer and gyro
geometry_msgs/Vector3Stamped -> raw magnetometer data
std_srvs/Empty -> enable_motors, stop_motors services
std_msgs/Bool (?) -> wifi connected status
MCU parameters to be reviewed separately.
Placeholder for MCU firmware comments:
sensor_msgs/IMU isn't meant for truly raw data. Will need to determine where is best to scale to m/s^2, etc
I like going from least complex to most. So, PWM, then SPEED, then TORQUE
The reason it's as it is so that speed is the default. This ordering is "order of likelihood that it's what you want".

If we're always going to be sync'd between motors (which we should be), should we make that clear in this part by explicitly creating left_* and right_* members? IMO it'll be easier than arrays when using CLI tools to monitor
Based on my experience with Grizzly, it comes in handy having them be arrays rather than named members. It's a lot easier to assign names to the members than it is to produce an array after the fact.
Is "drivers_active" the enabled status? Otherwise known as the "/ESTOP"?
Yes, but I'd prefer to avoid "estop" terminology, since it isn't really one.
If we change the message period, are we going to autoadjust this in in firmware (as in, is it worth the trouble)? Maybe just say "1 Hz" for the average

It's easier to go by publish period than to say that it will always be a 1sec average. (ie, someone changes the period to 5Hz for some reason, then you need to track 5 separate averages-in-progress, ugh)
For which voltage level? If we're talking all voltages, what's the use you've got in mind? IMO a "lowest battery voltage" would be more usable for diagnosing brownouts.

VBATT—I believe all the currents are being measured upstream of the respective regulators, and it's VBATT feeding the PC and motor drivers. The use is to alert the user of overall system current spikes which may not be visible in the 1Hz averages. I agree that lowest-seen voltage would be useful as well.
An alternative way to do this would be to define a CurrentFeedback message with avg, peak, variance, whatever, and then use instances of those in this message. I'm not sold either way.
Where do we report MCU uptime?
Should be here. That's missing, thanks.
re: sensor_msgs/IMU
The intent is that the MCU will publish a data message suitable for consumption by
, using standard REP-103 units.
So, scaling will occur on the MCU, controlled by rosparams.
Thank you, this was an obvious omission on my part and sadly not caught by the unit test. Please have a look at the inline comments prior to merging (especially change to
instead of
Thank you - can you please squash all the commits into one? If CI goes green after the squash, I'll merge.

pr_details_more: Each task map approximates joint velocity, acceleration, and jerk by backwards finite differencing using the previous 1, 2, 3 solutions respectively.
These task maps require the user to provide each newly computed solution (e.g. see
). As such, they can only be used for one-step optimization (e.g. teleoperation). To avoid this hack, deeper modifications for EXOTica are required.
demonstrating difference between smoothing and no smoothing. Uses
I've updated code quite a bit.
Rather than storing 1,2,3 previous vectors, these are now stored in a matrix.
A rebase on origin/master is required.
Default initialisations and fail safety needs to be provided.

pr_title: Fix OMPL state validity checking and debug output for out of joint limit goal states
pr_contents: Pair debugging/programming with Vlad, so merging as soon as Travis comes back green.
pr_details_more: Removes the unused, not compiling, and non-working

Fix default margin for collision checking for OMPL - reducing time taken to iteratively reduce margin (2.0m safety distance for sampling based planning was too high - it needs to be greater than 0.0 though, so 1cm)

Better debugging for failures on OMPL initialization, particularly when the goal state is invalid (most common planning failure) - i.e. output which joint is out of joint limits and what the corresponding joint limits are.

, this PR changes the initialiser code generator to require default arguments for
paramters.
It already triggered for the JointPose task map initiliasier (
) which is a Eigen Matrix type and would load garbage values if not set by the user.
What would be a good default value for these:

Lines 1 to 6
      in
Edit: I already made them
to let the CI pass.
I don't think they have triggered "garbage" values for
since it was correctly handled in the
call (and we frequently use
as a default-cost with the empty optional parameters, defaulting to "all joints squared/from zero"):

Lines 85 to 110
      in

I.e. since they are correctly handled in the implementation they neither need a default value nor need to be required. For double/int/other standard types, this is, of course, different - but for Eigen-types we usually handle it well.
These should be optional and set to empty vectors.
I think I found another, more narrow bug related to this and will update
with my findings shortly.
It appears to be limited to initialising manually from Python or without going through the XML-layer.
Having dug into the issue with the minimal example you provided it seems that there are two distinct things at play:
(a) To require Optional arguments to have a default parameter - what you are proposing to fix in this PR. This should go ahead. Please revert and fix the change to JointPose though.
(b) The fact that
arguments are not enforced if the initializer is passed manually via Python. If you create the same example in XML, it throws.

This PR only addresses the issue that Optional parameters should have default arguments (a). It's not related to the bug that you can initialise Required parameters without a value via a Python dict (b).
Regarding the

, I did not meant to say that garbage values will be loaded. For Eigen types, a class can always check of a dynamic sized matrix has been initialised. I just meant to say that if someone uses Eigen types like this without providing a default argument (or checking if it is initialised), it would provide garbage values.
Thank you for the fix :-) Happy to merge once CI goes green.

pr_contents: Please add sample and test, refering to previous works:
Thanks for very kind tutorials! Updated.
Yes, but result is different.(in original code, normal direction of plane is sometimes flipped) I don't know why. Do you know.??
I don't know. Please describe
in more detail.
Do you check that in Rviz or polygon instance of jsk_recognition_utils/geo in C++ code?
I think that distance < 0 and |distance| is larger than input polygon size, the clockwise/counterclockwise  of magnified polygon vertices might be flipped and then normal flipped.
I executed sample_polygon_magnifier.launch with this PR update, and it worked (normal was not flipped).
Then, I reverted
to origin/master, then build and executed same sample launch, and it also worked (normal was not flipped).
I need rosbag to check more. Could you give rosbag (or could you check once again) please?
Sorry for many reply comments.
I found one possible reason that normal is flipped.
The shrunk polygon might become non-convex even if the input polygon is convex because the polygon is shrunk with constant distance for all verticies (not ratio).
In the readme figure you add is good example. Green shrunk polygon is not convex if you see carefully.
If two edges of non-convex parts are used for calculating normal, normal is flipped from original. Is that make sense?
This can happen regardless of your change in
. My guess is that your experimental environment was changed slightly at the same timing that you updated the code.
reproduce normal flipping.
You are totally right!! Thanks! I'll write a code to warn if breaks original convex hull.
Green shrunk polygon is not convex if you see carefully.
If two edges of non-convex parts are used for calculating normal, normal is flipped from original. Is that make sense?
Sorry, if I understand correctly, you mean
? (not Green).
Updated thanks to your many advices. If you approve, I rebase all commits into one.
Sorry, if I understand correctly, you mean Red? (not Green).
I'm saying about this figure in this comment.
green polygon is a little bit non-convex.
If keeping convex (and not flipping normal) is important for your use case, I recommend you to use magnify by scale in nodelet, and add rosparam to select magnifying by distance or scale.
This is just a comment, and you don't need to do this in this PR.
Thanks for advice, updated / rebased and yes, I'll send another pull request to support
by scale factor when we want.
LGTM!
Hmm, failed on indigo...
OK. Test passed!

This PR is necessary in running global_planner onboard a real drone

Previously, octomap messages were being dropped and only one out of ten messages were being used.  This was done to prevent updating the map too frequently when the map is streamed at a high rate. However, there is no notion of update rates as the dropout depends on the rate the map is streamed. This will lead to drastically different performance depending on how powerful the compute platform is onboard the drone.

This PR switches to updating the map based on time. This information can be useful in defining the optimal replanning rate and maximum speed of the planner. The timeout is simply unblocking the trigger, and not necessarily making the update happen at a fixed rate.
A few clean ups were made on the way too
pr_details_more: Define the global_planner frame as configured from parameters

When updating the octomap, checking if the planner imporved is no longer done. This was only useful when replanning was triggered by events. Currently the planner will replan on a fixed time interval, therefore this check is no longer applicable.
Speed when passing trajectory has been increased to solve the decrepancy between offboard mode

pr_contents: The old stoplight watcher reacts more to people walking by than the stoplight itself. I reworked it to react only to circles which should require less tuning.

The new version using simple rgb math (no color matching) over the whole image to get the green and red light candidates. Once found, contours determine candidate green lights based on circularity. If a green light candidate is found, it looks in the past for a similarly sized red light above and nearby that position.
I also renamed the node to startlight_watcher to fix confusion since the light is made for starting races.
Good job! Worked well with the bag file I tested it on and I like that there is the ability to change the history buffer length. Minor comments but looks good enough to merge in my opinion.

Looks very good overall. I don't really have an intuition for why the formula to identify green circles works, but if it works then I have no problem with it. Also, maybe we could re-use the variables redImage and redCircles in lines 177 and 180, respectively? Also consider using std::queue or std::deque to add to the front of the history queue without copying 5 images. It's easy to read and understand the code, props for that
I don't think the variables redImage and redCircles can't be reused as they could not exist if there are no green circles found in the frame.

Hadn't heard of std::deque but that is exactly what I was looking for! Thank you. I wanted to leave it easy to implement checking multiple frames in the history instead of only the last in the buffer in the future which std::queue didn't allow. Changing to deque.
Merged as part of larger PR for IARRC competition 2019 in

pr_title: Added more debug and error information
pr_contents: Needed while I was debugging and setting up the trajectory controller.
The ROS logger is not realtime-safe. All the proposed log statements except the
take place in the realtime loop, so I can't merge them. Writing realtime code is like walking on eggshells ;-)
Ah, that's true.

But these error/debug messages are pretty useful and necessary for figuring out the state of the trajectory controller - its good software practice to have user friendly feedback. There needs to be some way to provide similar functionality. Also, it does seem to me that, though in the realtime loop, these messages will be output very rarely so won't
affect much, right?
Or, should we perhaps make some sore of
roslogger?
Or, should we perhaps make some sore of realtime_tools roslogger?
This is easier said than done. For example, std::stringstream isn't real-time safe.

What if we add an option in the controller configuration yaml named something like "nonrealtime_debug_ouput: true" and have some of my suggested user feedback info be used if that setting is used? it would of course default to false.
For the specific problem of the reason why the goal was aborted, the action goal result reports this information in the form of an
, which can be printed out by the clients in non-realtime. I recognize that it would be best to print it from the controller so the logging code lives in a single place.

More generally speaking, there's a compromise to live with here. The ros_control project so far does not contain RTOS-specific intrinsics, and strives to allow the same binary to work both on realtime and non-realtime deployments. Also, ros_control is rather light on dependencies.

OTOH, projects like Orocos generate separate binaries for different RTOS targets, and use RTOS-specific intrinsics. Orocos has good working solutions for most RT-related problems one might encounter like concurrencly handling, clock access and logging. Yes, there is a log4cxx (cousin of log4cpp) based reatime logger.

A good discussion would be to determine the extent to which it makes sense to put effort to Orocos and ros_control so they can work together. Being a 5-year Orocos user, I sometimes feel frustration of not being able to do in ros_control things I already took for granted in Orocos. YMMV.
On these lines
has been very quietly (but effectively) working on adding native support to ROS services and actions to Orocos, but he seems to not want to talk much about it ;-)

What if we add an option in the controller configuration yaml named something like "nonrealtime_debug_ouput: true" and have some of my suggested user feedback info be used if that setting is used? it would of course default to false.
Not my favorite option.
The FollowJointTrajectory error codes are nice, but I've been needing more info than just that, such as which joint caused the error, what the position/tolerance/values were, etc.
I've also been impressed with

's work with getting Orocos back up to par with the latest changes in ROS. I know Orocos is a very powerful set of libraries and I'm surprised to hear you have experience with it but don't still use it. I'm curious - why bother with ros_control at all? I only don't use it because its far more complicated and seems to have a much bigger learning curve than ros_control has had.
The FollowJointTrajectory error codes are nice, but I've been needing more info than just that, such as which joint caused the error, what the position/tolerance/values were, etc.
Very good point!. Noted.
I'm curious - why bother with ros_control at all?

Good ROS and Gazebo integration, there was already a good starting point, and ros_control is likely to reach critical mass. I'm still using Orocos, and I wrap my hardware abstraction inside it. With ros_control is in shape, we can start thinking of the next steps, and how to make it better (maybe by leveraging Orocos under the hood).

The new tests have been converted to type parameterized tests and moved into a header file. This header file may be included in any user code and will instantiate a standard battery of tests for any new planners.

+1...accepting as is.
, please address the issues these tests brought up ASAP.

This PR creates a trajectory ID class that encapsulates a unique state object. I tried to design the implementation so it will be easy to switch the underlying state object to any type we want (including UUIDs).

The current system works by keeping an atomic integer and incrementing it every time we generate a new point. This is very fast compared to making UUIDs and we save something like 90% of the time previously required. It has limitations though:

There might be more limitations and I invite conversation on what the right answer is. I find the performance improvement compelling and was my primary motivation for doing this. Trajectories of several hundred points solve more or less instantly for me now.

+1...while this is less powerful than the UUID, I don't see a compelling case that requires UUID.  The original reason for using UUID was convenience.  I'll keep this open for a few days to allow others to comment.

As a potential enhancement, what do you think about initializing the ID with a call to time() or clock() or a pseudo random generator?  As is, this is guaranteed to collide, although I'm not sure of the use cases where it would matter.

Depending on the time resolution and how time changes are handled or the random number generator specifics, there isn't a guarantee of uniqueness within or between processes.  UUIDs provide this guarantee but apparently at great expense.  The current approach can guarantee uniqueness  within a process, which is required at a minimum.

'm proposing to initialize with a pseudo random number which would still be guaranteed unique within a process since they are serially incremented after the initialization.  Between processes you would have a good chance of being unique, but if/when it fails, the result could be hard to detect/debug.  So maybe it is better to just do the simple thing and force the collisions to happen.
If we generated 1 million ids per second, we could operate for the next 2^64(1e6 * 60 * 60 * 24 * 365) =  584942.4 years before we overrun.
Sounds like
thinks there should be a check for overflow in the ID generation method. ;)
The nearest star, Proxima Centauri, is 4.01126E+19 millimeters from Earth.  If at 1 mm discretization, we will overflow twice before we finish the plan.  I recommend a 128 bit integer.

pr_title: Add controller_group script that allows switching groups easily

New member canStart checks if the given controller can be started (including HW interface switches) from the current state. For strict checking the switch fails if one controller cannot be started, otherwise it is filtered out.
We assume that controllers can be stopped at any time
After all checks are passed  new member doSwitch is called with filtered lists of controllers that start or stop, but not restart
All controller information needed for switching is contained in ControllerInfo
canStart was chosen in favour of the discussed canSwitch, because this simplifies the filtering and handling in general
doSwitch only gets updates, not the the full list, this should simplify the handling of stopped interfaces
doSwitch runs in the non-RT part, do you see any pros or cons for running it in the real-time part?

It checks controllers individually. Certain inconsistent configurations can only be detected with full knowledge of the end controller configuration. The previously discussed example of a differential transmission illustrates it. Two different controllers might want to use one joint of a differential each, but in different joint modes. Your hardware might not be able to support this.

pr_contents: I suggest this PR in order to introduce a HOLDING Mode which keeps the JointTrajectoryController running but moves the manipulator to the holding state. Further Trajectories are not accepted in the HOLDING Mode to avoid unwanted robot movement.
The changes don't affect in-field applications but would allow derived controllers to enter this mode e.g. via external service calls.
Could you please add a reference implementation in a form of a couple of tests?
It'd be ideal to have something that can be ran through some visualization as well.
About the name of
... We have a similar concept at the joint interface level, it may be confusing to call them the same way.
So in general you would give it green light?
I will provide some tests soon. By visualization you mean trajectories?
About the naming: My first idea was to call it a
however this would interfer with the controller_interface::ControllerBase which itself has a state. Any preferences on state/mode?
I would still go with
or maybe
for distinction.
Also mentions:
Sending an empty trajectory message from the topic interface (not the action interface) will stop the execution of all queued trajectories and enter position
. The stop_trajectory_duration parameter controls the duration of the stop motion.
Isn't this something that could be dealt with with a combination of
and having some higher level logic to avoid sending new commands?
I have a feeling that this kind of statefulness belongs in an application orchestration/coordination layer, rather than at the controller level.
Higher levels could send empty trajectories but you could not be sure that somebody else is sending another trajectory after or while you moveing into holding mode, leave aside staying there.
Higher levels could send empty trajectories but you could not be sure that somebody else is sending another trajectory after or while you moveing into holding mode, leave aside staying there.
Don't mean to sound overly critical, but neither can you be sure that somebody else isn't switching back to

mode and sending additional trajectories. Sure, it is an extra layer of security. I only wanted to state that I'm not totally on-board with the idea of the control layer being responsible for restricting access to the hardware.
Using Authentication to allow switching back to
mode would clearly be a overkill ;-)
I am also not really totally happy about the suggested solution.
But if look at it from a responsibility perspective I would argue that
the task to fully complete the hold-trajectory is the responsibility of the JointTrajectoryController and for that he needs the access to the hardware at that point.
I have trouble finding a solution that would not break the API but would still enable the desired behaviour. Any suggestions?
Closing for now since
would allow to implement the desired behaviour in a derived class.

pr_title: Split robot specific parameters into separate yaml
pr_contents: This PR creates a separate yaml file for the robot-specific parameters in the navstack (e.g. specific to turtlebot3 waffle model) and integrates it alonside
in the launch files. For different robot yaml files, they can be specified at command line via
I've left out changes to the
since it is currently incurring run-time failures due to ExecuteProcess and rosargs for params.
So I get what you were going for, but in practice, they really are
robot specific parameters. The number of samples Vx and Vy are also substantially related to the speed and controller frequency on the base, as well as the costmap sizes, etc.

I'm not sure I agree. Perhaps I should be more precise to say that I am aiming to separate robot characteristics or properties from tuneable algorithm parameters. Though you might change the number of samples Vx and Vy based on your robot's properties, I'd argue those are parameters to tune of the algorithm, not characteristics of the robot itself.

I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

Having 2 different files of parameters for a single program seems like it could be confusing. Someone looks at one file, makes the changes and is none the wiser that others exist. I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portability. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans

I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

I don't disagree that these parameters are influenced by the robot's properties, but I see them as tuneable, whereas the properties I'm suggesting to split would be innate (for the most part) to the robot itself.

Having 2 different files of parameters for a single program seems like it could be confusing. Someone looks at one file, makes the changes and is none the wiser that others exist. I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.

I thought this model with more than one file logically grouped was more convenient. I was considering either to remove the default robot parameters file from launch to enforce users to be precise about their robot and/or to block or error out the program if certain key robot parameters were not present in the yaml file. I'd argue that there may not be any sensible default that covers all robots, therefore we shouldn't allow the stack to progress (i.e. if no robot radius or footprint was specified).
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portbility. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans

I'd think a parameter to limit max speed for the controller (in consideration for safety/humans) could be a dwb-specific parameter. Yes, I had originally thought to separate out yaml files by stack module, but there were some implementation considerations given how we do parameter substitutions in the yaml.
I think it would make sense to move what lets call
, which I think are fairly ill-defined, into a specific yaml file would make sense if we were going back to to having some utility or server
that all of the nodes query for those parameters such that there is no redundancy and they are parameters that are uniquely hardware specific
Here's how I hoped this would play out over time.
After splitting out parameters that describe the physical characteristics of the robot (the

) We could then relate the other parameters back to those basic ones. Maybe they are just rough guidelines at first but eventually, we could perhaps compute them in some way, reducing the number of parameters users need to tweak.
Those examples you listed out - maybe we could provide guidelines that say, for example, the costmap size should be
or something like that. That is, relate all the algorithm tuning parameters back to fundamental parameters in some way.

if the longer term plan is to do that, then I think that it should be included here, right now, otherwise its a separation of information based on the promise of something in the future that no one's created a ticket and committed to working on actively. Keep in mind in the last few weeks the majority of my work here has been either reverting or refactoring code to fix problems of "we'll do this thing" that then never happens. I'd very much so like to stop that and start working on some of the motion planning work I'd like to have replace NavFn. As it stands in the PR, its separating parameters that

be physical values, but generally aren't (I dont know anyone actually sets their max robot speed in planners, or else there would be clearpath robots at 2m/s in shopping malls), from the rest of a packages settings.

ehhh.... I can see where you're going with that, but I'm not buying it as a way of removing parameters. Maybe give some "first guess" defaults, but doing something like that doesn't replace the need for the parameterization so it seems to be a bit extraneous. Could not be there at all and I dont know that its missing anything, could also be a markdown readme formula for someone to get started, could be code as you suggest
I'm just not seeing the benefit of organizing in this way unless there's something in someone's immediate queue  to implement a robot package-like server or these parameters are central to
packages and having another file would let us reduce duplication.
it was actually very much the original idea to put these parameters on a separate server node. For now, we held off on the parameter server given discussions on
and in issue
about remaining parameter features and design proposals needed for support. I saw this PR as a step in that direction, starting by identifying ownership of certain parameters.

If you're concerned about having a different limit on some parameters such as max velocity on a robot for a controller implementation, I would set that as a separate parameter in the controller node and keep the physical property separate with the robot parameters, because you could cap the velocity at the lowest between the two (if say, I have a slower robot). Semantically, there is a difference between the max "safe" velocity we'd ever allow in our controller (or perhaps "safe" depends on context) vs the max velocity the robot can nominally achieve. Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters. If we could think of parameters in these semantic terms maybe it'll be easier to decide where they should live.

Also, while I agree we shouldn't promise work that never gets done, I think the first step is to determine whether said thing is worth doing and with what importance. So if we should make a ticket to automate parameter tuning, then we should go for it and place it somewhere in our priority queue :)
Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters
But why? the existing parameter is the max speed
, not for the robot. No where in the stack to my understanding is a parameter for the robot's maximum speed. I think you may be reading the phrase
in some global sense as the maximum speed of the robot rather than its actual use
, the maximum speed for the dwb planner.

What function would there be in having the actual maximum robot velocity around in this codebase? No where here to my knowledge would need it. These aren't hardware limits, they're limits for individual packages and programs to use in computing their tasks. industrial robots can achieve dangerously fast speeds that are completely impractical (3 m/s) and even having that in software for someone to make the mistake of using it could be dangerous, unless there's a specific case where that is needed to compute some derivative value, but I'm not seeing any evidence of that.

I understand what the intent is, but I think there's some misreading what these parameters mean to the packages that define them, rather than some global parameter of robot dynamics. Lets play out that we have some
that hosts a set of parameters about the robot, with the exception of
in the
, none of the parameters have utility for other components in the existing stack. I'm not seeing strong evidence that the centralized parameter server serves too much of a purpose beyond setting
since the overlap seems to only be a parameter that happens to exist under the scope of a package executable which is instantiated twice.
I super love the idea of a
but I think that involves some substantial redesign of the stack that we're not totally prepared to do, which is in large part why I nuked the
package (and even then, we've now nuked 3/4 of the utility functions that survived)

I'll buy that for most industrial robots you would not approach those speeds/hardware limits, but I think there's the use case that some arbitrary robot may have limits that are not congruent with the defaults in the code. Even so if maintaining just the one parameter, per robot, there may be some parameters that are configurable by type of robot, which is why I proposed the logically grouping by robot as opposed to by the controller algorithm. I'm not really trying to argue specific parameters (like maximum robot velocity), but rather the justification of a logical grouping, where it seems I see the benefit and you don't so far.

On the robot server, I'd say looking ahead, if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack, I think moving towards a split robot parameters file would help us remove duplication and maintain modularity. I have a branch on my fork where I actually did experiment with a robot server/parameter blackboard concept and it wouldn't take too much modification to our stack.

Sorry, yes, I think I've fixated on the velocity as an example since the proposed file changes represent 3 major classes of parameters: speed limits, footprint size, acceleration limits. Speed and acceleration limits both follow the logic I have above so I thought it was a pretty representative example.
if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack

This is true, and if/when that happens I can see a stronger argument for having a set of robot-specific parameters around, however that still doesn't change the fact that any new package will include their own parameters, so now there's 2 different organizations of things to maintain and look between. You still have these parameters namespaced to their respective nodes

so they're still not portable, the file would need to be updated to reflect those changes in packages so that kind of nulls out that benefit. Another point is that if these are truly robot specific quantities, then this file should fully describe the robot in whatever meaningful way to navigation.

I think I've made my position clear. I think separating parameters that belong to packages not robots is confusing, if you don't want one long file of parameters, they should be split up by nodes. For any parameters that are genuinely needed across multiple units, a global parameter server makes sense. All parameters for these packages are effectively robot specific not only relating to the physical characteristics, but the compute power as well. Cherry picking things like kinematic limits as "more robot specific" than the compute platform to support more samples / costmap size / update rates / motion model parameters of noise / laser characteristics seems arbitrary
Take from that what you will...
Closing this PR due to lack of consensus. We may re-approach this topic if and when we address enabling a robot parameter server in the stack
pr_quotes: I'd say if your robot is 2 meters tall and a meter wide, then the size of the costmap is a robot-specific parameter, or if your robot is ackermann vs. differential drive, the Vx/Vy samples might be robot drivetrain specific.

I think for grouping purposes if you're trying to group parameters in not a mega-file, separating parameters by program.
Traditionally configuration files for sp. packages are in different files for more portbility. Ei my AMCL params are in another file than my costmap_2d parameters, from my DWB parameters, etc

In concept I dont mind organizing parameters differently, but if we move some params of [node A] we should probably move all the params of [node A] so that they're all together. Realistically over time I really do mess with all of them, since you don't actually (or at least me) tell DWB it can go as fast as the robot base is capable of since I dont want robots going 5 m/s next to humans
Given their semantic difference, I'd perhaps use two parameters
if we are introducing new planners, controllers, maps, and plugin interfaces to the stack
