pr_title: Multiple planner plugins server for contextual planning
pr_contents: This is a draft currently addressing the discussion to allow for multiple planners and controller to be available in each.
Right now its just the planner server being able to host multiple planners, but I wanted to throw this out here early for comments if someone has an issue.
My plan:
If anyone has strong thoughts on plugins within BT at this time, maybe we start here
If anyone has a better name than
as the map name for
plugin, let me know, I'm not good at naming things
Merging
into
will
coverage by
The diff coverage is
Powered by
. Last update
. Read the
In CI, I'm seeing this error:

However it can load fine locally. I have other test failures locally on unrelated packages (amcl test, costmap test) that i don't see in the CircleCI CI. I think everything is fine -- but I do recall a recent PR to change the location the the behavior trees are installed.
It seems all PRs right now are failing on this. I'll start on this tomorrow afternoon if no one beats me to it
fixes the XML path issue, but remains the issue with multirobot test failing on finding the spawn_robot node, see
If anyone has a better name than ComputePlan as the map name for NavfnPlanner plugin, let me know, I'm not good at naming things

If we're going to do it this way, well, seems like we should break out djikstra and A* as separate plugins. Then we'd have two ComputePlan plugins with fairly obvious names - "Dijkstra" and "A*". In the meantime, I'd just keep it as Navfn. Just my 2 bits. Take it or leave it.
Well conceptually you could actually load multiple instances of NavFn, one with A* the other with Dij!

But I'm not opposed to it, I can just make a wrapper plugin that sets the use_astar param on bringup. I think it's a little excessive to split them up personally since they accomplish the same class of task, but I dont have a strong opinion

I know we discussed this a couple months ago in the WG, but was a design issue ever opened so we could discuss this? I don't understand the use case that this is targeting and why it's an improvement.
I have a couple issues with this we should discuss in the Nav2 WG.
My thinking right now is that we can add "ComputePlan" but it shouldn't replace "ComputePathToPose".
since they accomplish the same class of task
What do have in mind for this feature, if not that? Every plugin you instantiate takes a goal pose and computes a path. They are all the same class of task, aren't they?
Lets talk in the meeting but high level
I don't understand the use case that this is targeting and why it's an improvement.

This allows multiple plugins for a server, both to share resources (costmaps, tf buffers, etc) and to share action interfaces. There's a planning action with a parameter as to which of the high level primatives to use, right now that's just NavFn mapped to ComputePlan (I think changing the mapped name to ComputePathToPose again would be reasonable).

Conceptually now you can have really interesting behaviors with different types of planners called in the behavior tree at different times. For instance if you have a security robot, then you could have a coverage planner going and once a person is detected, change from a full-space sweeping planner to a compute path to a position planner. Those are two such classes of planners but the list is much larger including multirobot planners, switching planners from static environments to save power to a time-variant planner when its highly dynamic environments. As you suggested in our last conversation, I'm mapping the names of the specific plugins to their tasks to give a level of abstraction between similar coverage vs. time-variant vs. "normal" planners. Another example is a retail robot who's goal is to scan shelves but may be interrupted by a customer to make the robot show them to an aisle, switching planners to a human aware planner would allow that all to happen within the behavior tree structure and without creating unique resources for each planner.
In terms of design doc, that seems overkill. Its just a map of plugins & a string name for planner to use.
ComputePathToPose as the name mapped to NavFn makes sense, but that verbage is extremely restrictive. A planner is

just something to make a plan to a position, there can be other classes of planners. We are indeed changing the action msgs definition, and that's why its important this change goes in right before a new distribution.

I have some concern about the behavior tree node having to know the details of the plugins they want. The actions are currently an abstraction layer between the BT and the implementation, but this seems to remove that abstraction. I could be convinced this is OK I suppose, but I guess I don't really see what problem this is solving?

We also talked about this and agreed that as long as we weren't specifying a plugin but a task to complete (compute path to pose, compute coverage plan, compute short time horizon, etc) and then the server has mapped a plugin to accomplish that task that would be fine.
My thinking right now is that we can add "ComputePlan" but it shouldn't replace "ComputePathToPose".

ComputePathToPose isn't really want the planner server is doing, its what the NavFn plugin happens to be doing, that name really needs to go. It can be remapped to the NavFn-like task of computing a path from start to goal, and I can change the mapped name + BT name for the mapped NavFn planner to that, but the  task needs to be more general. ComputePlan or ComputePath and similar is more  generic for all uses

Without allowing for contextual planners and controllers, I don't see the point in the behavior tree, so I view this as really critical to getting the advanced behavior and really unlocking the good work you all did on the behavior tree orchestrator
Action items
revisiting this with the reduced scope of: only planners for going to pose are intended, backward compatible if only 1 planner plugin loaded, and renaming the action server "topic" the same...
Is there an issue with leaving the
name as
rather than
to have greater re-usability since the items defined in the message are useful for other planning types? I plan to change all other references to
back. If you don't like it, that's fine and I'll change that back too, just verifying your thoughts.
revisiting this with the reduced scope of: only planners for going to pose are intended, backward compatible if only 1 planner plugin loaded, and renaming the action server "topic" the same...

Yes. Backward compatible meaning the BT doesn't have to include the plugin type. One thing I forgot to mention yesterday was that part of the reason we have an abstract action interface is so that people can implement their own planners in different languages such as Python if they want. Please make sure we don't break that requirement.
Is there an issue with leaving the
name as
rather than
I'd prefer you didn't, as that will mean the action name and message name are different, that seems confusing.
Again, as I said yesterday in the WG. If you want
, you could
it as a new action type, just don't replace the existing
. This would allow for the BT designer to use either one. The "simple" interface is the same -
and they don't have to know any details about the implementation, maintaining the abstraction. Or if they want finer granularity control, they can use
with the plugin(s) in mind. I think this would be a "best of both worlds" scenario and we could support it long term.
However, it seems you don't want both, so I think the compromise here is what we agreed to. You are basically adding an optional field to the

action interface that is useful when more than one plugin is used. I'm good with this as I think that since the field is optional we still get to maintain the abstraction by default, and only go under the hood when we want to. Essentially we have exposed some of the underlying details, but made them optional.
Ok. I’ll change the name of the message as well.

I resist the idea of having multiple action servers accomplishing the same task since that will add layers of confusion to a typical user when to use each when both will provide identical behavior in a typical application. This is acceptable for high level operations with GoToPose where we have an action and a topic but for internal structure I think that makes poor design and opens the gate for adding arbitrary number of additional nuanced servers. I believe that an algorithm developer creating a plugin should not have to deal with anything else in the navigation stack to enable their application since this is a ‘pro-user’ feature.
The interface Nav1 used was called GetPlan

with mostly the same content and that was not specifying that its a shortest-path planner. There are examples of ros planner plugins using the planner plugin to do coverage and other tasks and fit inside this general interface. It seems to me adding the specification to shortest path planning only is restrictive when it provides adequately the information required for many planning styles that the nav stack in ROS1 did support without an issue. Nav2 will also support if someone ignores the names of everything involved, which encourages off-design uses, or we just name things to be sufficiently general. If the action server name is specific, thats fine it can be remapped, but the message type used shouldn’t tell a user what it can and cannot do in my opinion.

Having the name ComputePathToPose everywhere reinforces the idea that the navigation stack can only support moving a robot from point A to B and that’s incorrect and I do not want people walking away with that impression. This is a configurable navigation solution that is as powerful as the algorithm plugins you can write.

I fundamentally don’t see the harm in using general terms when the interfaces will work for the general case. You and I can both come up with a short list of other planners that don’t fit in this general title, and they wouldnt have in ROS1 either (and they used GetPlan), and that’s when hosting your own server is reasonable when you’re up to something very very niche. The the edges cases shouldn’t affect everything else for defining the general usecase that are good for everyone else. We have a sensor_msgs/PointCloud2, works for 90% of what we need pointcloud datatypes for, but for very very niche things I’ve had to create my own. This is no different as I can see it.

Rabble rabble rabble. I’ll change the message back to. We can continue this spirited inquiry at another point. This will enable what I’m looking for but wouldn’t be clear to outside users that you can do those things.
I got a few comments on the PR but I'd like to start with clarifying the action description because the rest depends on this.
The interface Nav1 used was called GetPlan

with mostly the same content and that was not specifying that its a shortest-path planner. There are examples of ros planner plugins using the planner plugin to do coverage and other tasks and fit inside this general interface. It seems to me adding the specification to shortest path planning only is restrictive when it provides adequately the information required for many planning styles that the nav stack in ROS1 did support...
I'm ok with adding a field to the message that specifies the type of planning to do (but not the planner to use) for example
. If I understand correctly, that would solve
of the problem you describe.
Other types of plans require more information than a single point, for example, (as you mention above) coverage. For that, I would consider creating a different action.
I have similar comments on the PR for the controller

I am summarizing my position, I'm making the changes as requested but mentioning the fact that this interface was taken from ROS1 with a more general name and was used by people to implement other types of planners. I for one already do use that interface for a global coverage plugin.
I don't want to continue beating this with a stick.
is exactly the field you describe. Things are getting renamed to ComputePathToPose
...planner_name is exactly the field you describe.
OK, I got confused with the naming. Do you think
would be better?
see comments in the controller,
and
are meaningful in pluginlib so:
the
is the map-able name for the plugin which can be anything. The
and
are the actual classes of the plugin implementations, as specific as you can get. With this notation, we have to make then the parameters
as well since the pluginlib authors are going to be the ones adding those configs to the config file after registering their plugin.
So up the chain to the action file definition, we could I suppose flip definitions, but that's pretty un-ideal. I think
is a good suffix, or at least anything that isn't
. We could even make it just
If the tag is
do you think in context we could just use plainly:
, ei
take a look things have been renamed.
Only place that the word
appears in is the
callback method:
since the
computing a plan seems like a reasonable renaming
changed names. Merging on CI

pr_title: Lifecycle manager services/clients and transitions refactor
pr_contents: This PR refactors the
services/clients
In particular:
I'm open to suggestions on the naming of things in this PR.
I might rename “Command” to “LifecycleState” or the like so standing alone “Command” could mean robot-command state-command, etc.
“ManageNodes” -> LifecycleTransitionNodes for similar but less obvious reasons.
There’s also no reason the “Command” message isnt just in the service call unless you think the msg file will have reuse.
I was trying to distinguish the naming from a normal lifecycle node state transition (there is
and
) and make it clear this is for the lifecycle manager we've created in the stack. I agree "Command" may be too generic, though.
How about "LifecycleCommand" or "SystemCommand" since these are system level control?
what's wrong with just using
and
? Certainly they're more descriptive than what you're proposing but their in the same vein.

If lifecycle manager is a lifecycle node that manages the lifecycle of other lifecycle nodes (dear god, I had to read that 4x to make sure it made sense), then I think you should be able to mess with it using normal lifecycle rules in a meta-lifecycle way. If that's more annoying, power to you to make messages.
I'm bad with names, but
and
sound reasonable, though I'd bring up the single file of
if you don't forsee needing the
file separated for a pub/sub usecase
I suppose I didn't want to overload the terminology of
as it is presented in the existing
, the same for
. Since, for example,
, and

invoke multiple actual Transitions of each node, I didn't think it is a one-to-one matching of terms, otherwise we would have just exposed each transition (configure, activate, deactivate, shutdown, cleanup) directly. If that's the direction we want to head, then we can consider that.
I'm okay with consolidating into just the
file.
Also, the
is just a regular node, not a lifecycle node :)
Ah ok.
I suppose I didn't want to overload the terminology
I am not an expert on the lifecycle terminology, so if I'm redirecting a name to my different definition, certainly ignore me.
If its just the srv file
is I suppose another option, though I find myself wanting to add the word
at the end, but then the use of
which is weird. You're asking the lifecycle manager to change some node to some state.
... none quite feel right to me
To throw my 2 cents into the naming discussion ...
If you throw the command definition into the srv like
suggested, you avoid needing to come up with a name for that message altogether.
I kind of like
for the name, but I think I might extend that to
to avoid any ambiguity.
Merging
into
will

. Read the
do the changes in my last commit address your issues?
LGTM

uint8 STARTUP = 0
uint8 PAUSE = 1

pr_contents: This PR add CI support for CircleCI.

Like Travis, CircleCI is a Continuous Integration service, however CircleCI provides more docker integration such as support for custom images without resorting to machine type executors. This means that CI jobs can start as soon as they are triggered, rather than queuing for an available Virtual Machine to then spin up. The pulling of the Docker Image is perhaps the only main flat overhead in triggering jobs. Further features such as caching and storage of artifacts additionally accelerate job times while providing insight into build and test results.

The proposed CI would start with pre-build Docker Image, hosted on automated repo on Docker Hub that would trigger tag builds upon new commits into particular GitHub branches or rebuilds of linked Docker Hub repos, i.e.
base image. Built tags would include all/most the necessary dependencies for the project, include any build dependencies for prerequisite dependencies, i.e. running
, etc. on the master branch. Even when short cutting the install time by building
the
base image, this takes about 90 min on Docker Hub, so it helpful to offload/bake this amount of setup into the image our CI pulls from.
Once the CI pulls the docker image above, the config proceeds to clean the workspaces and checkout the source to inspect. This also entails

ing and prerequisite defined in the new checked out source, installing the prerequisite dependencies, building the prerequisites themselves, installing the source packages dependencies, building the source packages, then testing the source packages.

In between steps in the job of the workflow, caching of the build stages for both prerequisite and source packages is attempted. Caches are broken with either the installed dependencies change or the source code has changed. This allows the cache to persist across jobs.
An example of current table of caching in action:
Lastly, the log files for the colcon build and test steps are also archived and made linkable by storing them with the job's public artifacts.
DockerHub
CircleCI
Is the performance gain largely because you've switched to CircleCI or is it because you're starting from
? If we switch to CircleCI, do we still need to have Travis as well, or can we do everything within Circle to keep things simpler?
Is the performance gain largely because you've switched to CircleCI or is it because you're starting from ruffsl/navigation2:master?

, its partly both. Most of the upfront time is saved by starting from a Docker Image prepped for the CI with common dependence pre-installed, but then some more is also saved by making use of the caching between jobs. We could perhaps save even more by enabling
, but this currently seems to be a premium feature from CircleCI.
If we switch to CircleCI, do we still need to have Travis as well, or can we do everything within Circle to keep things simpler?

Well, I'm not sure. You could have both if you wanted, don't think it would be much drain. You might want to have only one or the other CI enabled for PRs to prevent too much integration noise. CircleCI might be better for this, as long as we can keep the quick turnaround times I've tabled above.
I'm not sure Travis has the same
as CircleCI, so it may still be well suited for longer builds via periodic cron jobs. E.g. just rebuilding the whole Dockerfile daily via master branch and run the stock tests and code coverage.
Also ping
, I've updated the top PR comment with more details.

I'll admit I don't understand the details of docker cache breaks yet, but I see no harm in adding Circle CI. It would definitely be nice to have faster feedback from the CI system, and it seems to best way to get a feel for Circle vs Travis is to turn this on and get some experience with both side by side.

org.

pr_contents: This is to improve system stability and ease of traceability
Can you give an example of when you might want to disable waiting for TF? I can't think of any - its a critical piece of this package. If you think it makes it unstable, why it is default
and not default

-  Putting the wait for transform in the constructor isn't really necessary, it can be waited for when it is actually used. In this case it waits for it but doesn't use it inside the constructor at all. Thus it is blocking waiting for something it doesn't need yet. Because it is blocked, we have seen that if the constructor never exits, the node time never gets reset by setting the use_sim_time parameter to true, and thus it hangs waiting for the tf forever. It's kind of a deadlock state.

The other option, and I can make this change if it's preferred, is that instead of the 'while' loop where it keeps rechecking for the transform, it could just check once, and if it isn't there, print the warning and move on. I could make that change if its preferred.
My main point wasnt that it shouldn't be included, but that it should not default to
but
because the typical application will want it to be true.
You might be getting into a deadlock state as well because there's no sleep in this while loop so its going to consume a core. That should definitely be changed.

The plugins need TF to be ready to operate. If you don't block until TF is ready and you start processing commands without TF available, that's a safety critical condition that could create a collision.
- if the transform isn't present, it will try the transform later and catch the failure here:

Line 449
      in
So if the transform fails, the robot won't move.
Failing to update the map doesnt stop someone from processing a motion planning request with empty costmaps

You're right, I guess the robot can move, it just won't get the map update. But can't that case still happen anyway? I mean if the transform is working at construction time, then it goes away, or freezes up, you would still hit the case you're talking about.
I'll back that change out of this PR and see if I can get things working without it. If I can't I'll re-submit on another PR later.

Sure, but going down I believe is the users fault, this would be a bad startup procedure. Many robots will power on and when ready immediately process commands, if the constructor blocks it makes sure all the tools have what they need to process. The 2 biggest things I want to see is default

so that unless a user goes out of their way to specify they dont want to wait, it will do the conservative (and in my opinion rational) thing. Second being that you issue a stern warning to users that do pass on waiting and its not up that they could indeed collide due to empty maps.

Steve, I don't mean to argue. I'm just trying to get things working reliably right now. If you haven't had a chance yet to try running the code now would be a great time to start. We're trying to debug issues and there seem to be quite a few due to the lack of message filters and the parameters changes in ROS2. There's no global 'use_sim_time' so every node needs to have the parameter set, and sometimes it doesn't seem to take correctly in the launch file. We're trying to debug these issues now. Anyway, that's another issue I should probably file.
Oh and I backed out the change.

Sorry, As well, just trying to make sure things are safe. To me, that takes total priority over functioning and other considerations. If this navigation framework has little quirks that lets people easily get themselves in trouble, we're going to be having a near impossible time getting any major people (or myself) to move over to it to continue the development and push the community forward (and potentially company ending lawsuits). Simulation should be a first class recipient of support, but all defaults and considerations should be focused on hardware as that's where it counts.

pr_contents: The algorithm must not walk upwards, thus the minimum value must be saved between loops.
(The old method breaks, when start position equals end position)
heads up to
I'm not sure I follow the motivation of the proposed changes.
I fail to see how the algorithm will behave any differently if the start position and the end position are the same, with the addition of the PR.
It is true that the minimum value should continually decrease as the path planning goes on, but I don't think it is necessary to enforce that.
Sorry, for the late reply, I'm currently lacking internet.

I found a  constellation with use_grid_path: true, use_dijkstra: false and start approx end where the loop won't exit The result is a bad alloc exception, when the vector get's too large. That's bad so you need to change something. Unfortunately I'm not familar with the move_base setup. Maybe there are some more parameter which influence this behavior.
The image shows the potential when this happens. Here start is cell (390, 75) and end is (391,73). The path toggles around (390,74) and (389,75) infinitely.
So there might be no minimum at the start position. Thus this is a problem of the potential, not traceback. But it would be nice not to get a bad alloc, when this happens.
To answer your questions
Any of the adjacent cells have a value less than 1e10. Thus the original algorithm always finds a (min_x, min_y) and the condition (min_x == 0 && min_y == 0) will never be hit.
There is at least one case where this results into a bad alloc exception.
With the change, the condition will be hit eventually.
This might happen, when start == end, but also when the potential does have local minimas. In the other cases the algorithm should behave identically.

This alorithm can not walk upwards. If there's a local minimum it would just walk back and forth until the memory is full. Of course it's up to your, how to handle that case. In terms of computing power the fix is really cheap.
I think
fixes the problem with the potential you found,
. Please let me know if that branch works for you.
Also, testing this use case made me shut down my computer twice, so I hope you're happy! :-) That's clearly suboptimal behavior.
I'm glad you found the aktual bug behind this behavior.
woks for me.
Those infinite loops are anoying ;-)
It's not important, but IMO the loop will never hit the condition
if (min_x == 0 && min_y == 0)
return false;
As you added a loop couter, that might not be worth the effort looking into it.
If there's a valid path, yes, it will never hit that condition. I'm not too worried about it though.
Closing this in favor of

pr_title: Fixes connection problem with mongodb first time it creates the database
pr_contents: This solves issue

. It turns out that the first time a robot is launched it takes a lot of time creating the  mongo db (from 100 to 150 seconds). So I added an initial sleep to allow moveit to load and increased the timeout to connect to the database and it does now manage to connect after a while. I also added a confirmation message when it connects successfully.
Wow, 100 seconds is
Wouldn't you say it makes sense to have a separate script then to create the db in the beginning?
What do you think about adding such a script instead and abort if the db is not yet there, saying something like "you did not setup your database yet. run
to do this"

The database is actually created but I guess the first time it needs that much time to set up before it can allow connections to it. Therefore the connector needs to wait for it. This is what is happening when the timeout is increased.
it takes a lot of time creating the mongo db (from 100 to 150 seconds).
This seems like a pretty serious bug in itself - there's no reason it needs that long unless you are running some insanely under-powered computer

I am using a powerful laptop but usually using moveit inside non-nvidia dockers and I get this issue all the time. I asked a colleague with a table pc and the current timeout is enough for him, even with a non nvidia docker so I think we can close this issue for now, until maybe somebody else could confirm that this is happening in other machines as well.
: something to check perhaps is to see whether your laptop has an SSD. If it doesn't, the db initialisation could be IO bound, and waiting on your HDD to complete the read/writes.
If your colleague does have an SSD (or a faster HDD, not difficult when comparing to a laptop), he would be less affected.
pr_quotes: it takes a lot of time creating the mongo db (from 100 to 150 seconds).

pr_title: PS: Don't reset color information of existing objects when new entries are added
pr_contents: This implements a fix for

When adding two different objects with color information one after the other (in two different PlanningScene updates), the color information of the first update is lost and overwritten during the second update.
As a result the color specified in the first update is lost and the existing (the first) object changes back to default-green in RViz.
In order to avoid memory leaks, I added explicit remove operations upon object removal.
However, this slightly changes current behavior: If you add an object with color information, remove it, and later on add that object back
specifying a color, the previous color was still cached - That is, unless any other PlanningScene update with color information was received in between.
Because of the changed behavior I would not backport this to i/j.
While I read through the code I found the explicit removal operations where missing for
s too, so I added these in a second commit.
Notice that both remove functions do nothing if the entry is not present, so calling them cannot break anything here.
LGTM, thanks!
Ruben's idea of fitting a cubic spline to a trajectory is a very good one:
.  Forcing the trajectory to a cubic should prevent the controller from overfitting the data, the problem presented here:

I've taken the concept a little further by repeatedly fitting the spline and adjusting timestamps until all constraints are satisfied.  This is similar to the way IPTP works, but instead of using local averages, the instantaneous values are used instead.

This technique is presented as another trajectory time parameterization class that can be used instead of IPTP.  It also adds some simple unit tests.  Initial/final velocity and acceleration can be specified.  The constraints imposed are velocity, acceleration, and jerk.  Here is a straight-line trajectory of 11 points:

Ruben graciously provided some sample trajectories using RRT-Connect with a Kuka IIWA in a fairly cluttered scene. The trajectories have between 25 and 70 waypoints.  These are the resulting spline trajectories (this is the calculated/interpolated spline curves, it is not data from an executing robot or simulation).
Thank you!
, if you could please help with testing, I'd be much obliged.  I haven't worked with robots/ros/moveit in years.
If you plan to compare against 'optimal' methods such as TOPP, just disable jerk.
I've been following this development and this is impressive. The 'staircases' in the jerk plots are very nice to see.
One comment / question: should compile time switches like (en|dis)abling jerk limits (
) and the default limits (
) all be made configurable / runtime changeable (ultimately through ROS params / dyn reconfig)?
I don't think we can choose a configuration / set of parameters that will suite every usecase or (robotic) setup, so it's probably worth it to make them user configurable.
Great code, fantastic contribution, small changes requested, thanks!
Yes, you are correct.  I wasn't initially sure if disabling jerk would play nice with the controller problem in
, but I believe it will.  We just lose initial/final acceleration matching.

So to that end, I've added arguments to the constructor for jerk enabling and setting the jerk limit.  And I've added a jerk scaling factor similar to the velocity and acceleration scaling factors in computeTimeStamps().  This will allow reducing limit during operation without reconstructing the object.
As for the default limits-- they are really just a fallback if the model doesn't provide them.  This is the same behaviour as IPTP, so I'd prefer to leave that out of this pull request.
Your requested changes should be complete.  Thanks for reviewing.

This is great! I'll definitely try to test the performance as soon as I can. A decent comparison between this and the other available options will be a little more work, but I'd be happy to merge this as soon as it is confirmed that the controller won't do anything weird with this parameterization (which I really doubt).
Seems like
(and
) will also need to be extended in order to fully use and configure jerk limits from the kinematics.yaml :)
Waiting on
's testing
What is your current view on this issue?
Has there been any progress here that is not documented in the issue?
I assume there is no optimal solution to the acceleration spikes available in the near future.
What do you think is the best way to handle this issue for now (also w.r.t.
I haven't looked at this in a while. I'd probably hold off on
until there is actually something better available. It's not perfect the way it is, but at least it is an improvement from what was there before.

Sorry guys, the only way I have been able to resolve to oscillations problem is to ignore the jerk constraints.  Smoothing is a promising option, but I've run out of free time to continue working on this.

So I've removed the jerk constraints from this trajectory fitter.  This improves on IPTP in the ways you were expecting (it's velocity&acceleration-constrained at waypoints, it's 1st/2nd derivative are continuous, calculation time and trajectory length are on par with IPTP).  I've tested on 3 sets of test trajectories provided by you.  But could If I could get some more help testing, I'd be much obliged.

the code is ready, if you'd like to use it.  It should solve the acceleration spikes issue.  However, it looks like this PR has fallen off everyone's radar.

pr_title: Remove an unused variable from the tf2_eigen test.
pr_contents: While we are in here, also kill off some trailing whitespace.
Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette

The kinetic build is "unstable", but in the same way that all previous builds are; it looks like it mostly comes from the eigen compatibility stuff for older distributions.  So I don't think we need to worry about that one w.r.t. this pull request.

The jade one also is "unstable", for the same reason as the kinetic one.  The odd thing is that all the previous (and subsequent) builds are marked green, while just this one is flagged for being unstable.  Not sure what is going on there.
The jobs are marked as unstable if there are compiler warning only since kinetic (so not for Jade and Indigo).
The jade failure is unrelated to the warning, it's due to a test failure

Oh, right, now I see.  I must have clicked on the wrong thing before.  Thanks for the heads up.  That failing test looks unrelated to this PR; tf2_ros doesn't depend on tf2_eigen in any way, and I didn't touch any other code that would change that (as far as I can tell).

Yes it looks like a flaky test based on the job history. The compiler warning should be fixed though because otherwise the maintainer will receive an email for every PR opened and commit added to this repo
Yeah, I agree.
ended up doing a fairly nice solution for eigen_stl_containers; I'll look at porting that over to tf2_eigen.
In any case, that problem is independent of this PR, so we can address it separately.

pr_contents: This is the completed dashboard for RQT. It currently displays kill status, operating mode, battery voltage, system time, and the IP and network status of all network enabled devices on Navigator. It also has a control panel that implements most of the functionality of the X-Box controller (actual keyboard driving of the boat is in the works).

Test day was a surprisingly good time for edge case testing and I was able to take care of all of the ones I found while the boat was in a state of chaos, so it should be fairly stable. If any additional display or control features are needed, just ask. I made it very simple to implement new ones.

Create and alarm broadcaster and raise the
alarm

I just had a few more questions to make sure we are on the same page here. Does the alarm get cleared once the system enters station holding? Should the KillBroadcaster and SetBool parts of the station holding function be removed? What severity should be used (I went with a severity of 1, allowing something in the priority queue to supersede it while still keeping it fairly high)?

Point noted. The language in the alarms page of the Sub8 wiki is a little confusing on the issue in that it makes it sound like the severity is used internally: "When many alarms must be handled, they will be handled as a priority queue...."

pr_details_more: alarm gets automatically cleared whenever the boat starts station holding.
KillBroadcaster and the SetBool service are a thing of the past

The severity is ignored internally. It is used right now only for human assessment of a situation, ie. seeing an alarm went off and not knowing what the alarm means but based on the severity, determining if it is important or not. All alarms are dealt with with equal importance. With that being said, I would make it 3 so that the user shouldn't have to worry about that alarm.

pr_title: BUS VOLTAGE: widen window for bus voltage estimate
pr_contents: The window seems a little big to me. We're really still looking to just throw out an outlier reading right? We still want to kill pretty quickly if the battery is actually low.

The bus voltage actually drops momentarily during transient periods with high thrust output, but then recovers after it. It's more like something to filter transient periods than a single reading outlier remover.

The way I understand our batteries (which could be completely wrong) is that there is a cutoff voltage where we should stop using them. Even if they only dip below that voltage while moving, isn't that still bad for the batteries in the long term?
We can ask

what the optimal value is. I think as it is right now, there is a safety margin above that value where it is harmful for the batteries. I've had the sub kill at about 45.5 volts because it momentarily dipped below 44 volts (kill voltage).
Merging since there have been no further comments, and we can always just modify the kill voltage.

pr_title: PERCEPTION: add automatic robust image segmentation
pr_contents: This pull request adds robust segmentation capabilities to the sub8_perception package.

It is designed to segment out foreground objects of solid color whose color distribution does not significantly overlap with that of the background. It tries to find the foreground distribution's mode and calculate ideal threshold values by finding specific zero_crossings of the histogram's derivative.

This method makes segmentation of solid colors extremely robust to lighting changes and some color loss, since no hardcoded thresholds are used. In my tests, telling it to look for hue distribution peaks from anywhere from red to green all resulted in successful segmentation of the yellow torpedo board.
The following image shows this in action:

pr_title: Added timeout to logblock stop in Crazyflie_cpp
pr_contents: If Crazyflie is switched-off while connected, the Crazyflie object locks on removing log block if it is deleted.
This commit adds a timeout of 50 packets to remove a log block.

Hi Arnaud, Thanks for your pull request. I have another branch (requestBatching), which adds a much better handling of the communication, including timeouts for all communication. However, the "downside" is that it actually throws an exception in case a timeout occurs, which seems not the desired behavior in your case. Do you have any thought on when exceptions are reasonable and when not?

For now, I can merge this, since it seems to be a good change for your remove/add Crazyflie use-case. In the future, I want to merge the requestBatching branch and would like to prevent "surprises" which might be created by thrown exceptions.
Thanks!
Hi Wolfgang, I agree a more generic way would be better but since this allowed me to fix my problem I though I would share it. Thanks for merging!

As for the exception, as long as the crazyflie_server does not die it will not break my use case. One problem I actually have is that if I remove a Crazyflie for more than a second all topics from this Crazyflie will freeze and will reappear only about 12 seconds after the Crazyflie is re-added. To mitigate that I remove and add the Crazyflie quickly which seems to work (and it makes it even more important to be able to remove a disconnected Crazyflie, since I will change the battery before removing the crazyflie from ROS). I am guessing this is happening because I am not using ROS topics the way it is suppose to by removing/re-adding topic dynamically.

pr_title: `move_base_interruptable_server` seems to be causing `move_base` to crash
pr_contents: Seems to happen when
tries to call
, but only sometimes.
I'm in the processes of investigating why this happens.
I did a little more investigating this morning, including capturing a core dump (thanks for the tip,
First, I'm not actually sure that this is a problem with
. I'll leave the title of this PR as-is for now, but it may need to be updated going forward. The reason I say this is because I rebuilt after commenting out a large portion of
and the problem didn't go away.
I'm now thinking that this could possibly be a bug within the ROS navigation stack itself. I ran our

node in GDB in a separate terminal, and, after a long while (I'm still unsure as to how to reliably reproduce this bug, which is worrisome), found Leela motionless at a door with the following output in the
terminal  (entire core dump is available on Leela at

Obviously, the backtrace here wouldn't be able to implicate any of our BWI code even if it was at fault, but the fact that the error occurs so many levels deep is why I wonder if this is some kind of bug in the ROS navigation stack. Specifically, I wonder about the
code, which is implicated in the lowest-level frames.
I'm not exactly sure what the path forward is at this point, so I'm open to suggestions. Perhaps next I'll try switching our
's
from
back to the default
to see if that makes a difference.
At first glance, there seems to be enough information to open an issue in
It's probably worth checking whether
is related.
, that does seem like it could be very related! Though we don't seem to get that exact warning message. I suppose to test this, we'd have to compile our own navigation stack from source and use that.
Another theory I've had is that this somehow related to the way we (BWI) deal with the map. Specifically, when monitoring Leela during
, I've noticed that the map seems to refresh after every completed goal. Further, these crashes are only occurring

the goal locations themselves (doors). Is there perhaps some kind of weird race condition cropping up here where the planner is trying to use a costmap that has temporarily been deleted because it's being replaced by some other BWI process?
, are you able to comment on this?
OK, I tried out switching the global planner to
today, and Leela ran without issue until the battery gave out.
Assuming this passes further testing, this would seem to indicate that our issue might be specific to the
code, or at least the particular way we interact with it.
I want to test this out a few more times in order to make sure this has really resolved our issue.
I also want the extra test runs in order to make sure Leela actually navigates smoothly in the hallways: I already found, for instance, that I needed to remove the
line in
in order for it to not get "stuck" sometimes.
Tested this for a few more hours today and all seems well: Leela seemed to run smoothly and without crashing.
So I'm going to go ahead and merge this into
I'm also going to open another pull request, perhaps destined to last a very long time, to figure out how we can switch back to
. There, we could, for example, try building the latest navigation stack from source and see if recent changes have fixed this or if we can track down the bug ourselves.

and I have done over the last few months. This new PR & branch is a cleaner way to get the results of that work pulled in.

pr_title: Added remove_crazyflie service to Crazyflie driver
pr_contents: Added a service to remove a Crazyflie.

The new service disconnects and remove a Crazyflie which allows to add it again later. This is added to be able to run continuous demo and, for example, change battery of a Crazyflie without restarting the complete system.
Thanks! I was always wondering why that is useful, but this is a pretty cool use-case. Also, with your changes it should now be possible to do a proper clean-up when the server exits.

Adds data subscribers for RobotState (battery voltage, faults, CAN metrics, etc) and for JoyFeedback (joystick rumble). RobotState data is displayed on the UI, JoyFeedback data is currently unused since joysticks are not yet supported.
pr_details_more: I have detailed my changes as much as possible.
I have auto formatted using clang-format or yapf.

pr_contents: Boost > 1.7 has signals by default
Thought I'd look around at this in case it helps decide what to do.
I don't know that the boost 1.7+ justification can be used, as
caters to
and
is
That said, there is precedence for this, and perhaps it's even "proper" to remove
I don't really understand cpp, nor boost nor signals, but hoped to point in a few helpful directions for the maintainers here.
Boost signals (v1) was

Signals (v1) is now removed. Its removal was announced in 1.68 and its deprecation was announced in 1.54. Boost 1.68 is the last release that provides this library. Users are encouraged to use Signals2 instead. The Boost community thanks Douglas Gregor for his work on Signals which served its users well and which also inspired Signals2.
Because of this, the
package fails to build on Boost 1.69+. The fact that this package builds successfully with 1.69+ after this PR is applied shows that it does not actually depend on Boost signals.

doesn't even have it in

pr_title: added options to start and end state dropdowns
pr_contents: The current default behavior is unintuitive, and may be wrong. Changing
the start state in the graphical interface does not impact the plan
generated--it just starts from the robot's current state. The sematics
of
are unclear, and apparently different for the start state
and the end state.
I added the "Query Start State" option to the Start State dropdown menu,
and similarly "Query Goal State" for the Goal State menu. These options
intuitively correspond to the states defined in the graphical interface.
I also made them the default options.
Please explain the changes you made, including a reference to the related issue if applicable
Thanks for helping in improving MoveIt and open source robotics!

Sorry, this PR doesn't make sense to me. The comboboxes are used to initialize the corresponding state in the GUI interface. There is no need to add "Query Start State" and "Query Goal State" to the start resp. goal combo box.
The sematics of "" are unclear
What are you referring to? There shouldn't be an empty string entry. If so, it probably comes from a named pose with an empty name.
Sorry, that empty string is supposed to be

I was working through the "MoveIt Quickstart in RViz" tutorial, but changing the Query Start State in the interactive interface did not affect the planner--it always started from the robot's initial state. So, when you get to the point shown in
, the green arm is ignored--instead, this happens:
Maybe I'm misunderstanding the semantics of those comboboxes. The only way I could get it to plan from an initial state of my choosing was by selecting
and then moving the arm.
Thanks for explaining the underlying issue in more detail. The culprit is the following code:

Lines 175 to 177
      in
which explicitly resets the modified start state to the current state. I introduced this code in
for a good reason. Obviously we need another fix to it.
Hm. I can't reproduce the issue of
after reverting it. Obviously this solves the issue. I will commit this fix...

pr_contents: Use the longest A* path weighted by cost, since we don't plan all of the way to the goal.
Before, the path chosen could have been any of the green cells, right up to the point of finding the red cell.
(play around with it
Now, it will find roughly the longest path until it actually reaches the end.
Happy for comments on what exactly we can do for a quick win here to improve the choice mechanism for the A* when it only plans partially.
I think this is great!

An approach I like personally on dealing with partial planning is using intermediate goals on a receding horizon. By selecting the intermediate planner smartly, we can also make the global navigation behavior fairly smart if we add global heuristics on selecting the intermediate goal such as the
SITL test before:
After:
There's definitely an improvement, especially in the occasional odd big 'jump' that doesn't happen anymore.
Is this something that helps short-time?
IMO yes, it needs real-vehicle testing and some more time in SITL though, since it changes the core A* path choice.

This code generates a reference trajectory which minimizes snap.

The class MinimumSnapReferenceTrajectory takes r (order of the derivative, r=4 for snap), tau_vec (a vector of time intervals), and a path (n by 3 matrix) and calculates the optimized polynomial coefficients, P (10*(n-1) by 3 matrix).
Then this P is used to obtain states (ParticleState) and control (Snap) at a given time, by using a member function, atTime(double t).
Output of the unit test can be checked by using
rosrun aerial_autonomy aerial_autonomy-minimum-snap-trajectory-test

Tested and works.

The biggest improvement is that I think I've gotten around the issue where systemd wouldn't fully start until a monitor was plugged into the robot.  The initial workaround was to change the default "target" from graphical to multi-user, resulting in GDM3 not running.  The current solution is just to disable Plymouth.  Caveat: I haven't been able to get back into this state even after re-enabling plymouth, so I'm not 100% confident in this.

I also redid how we specify grub config additions. The new way will avoid users getting confused during install regarding "updated" versions of /etc/default/grub.  (However, users who have already upgraded to 18.04 will likely encounter this prompt next time they do an apt-get upgrade...)

Alright, passes tests. There's a couple of asterisks I wanted to bring up explicitly.

I had to add a 10% margin to some tests because they were reallly close but not quite on the ball. This is due to the creation of a node in each test so it takes a bit for the network traffic to make connections and I'll typically see about 10% of messages dropped. I think that would account for this change required.
Another thing is the
test
. What I'm seeing is that the actual value of
required to be changed to

to pass. I consistently saw this and even after pulling out a bunch of ROS2 traffic metrics to see if this was a case where also some margin was required, but no. Even when I changed the QoS profiles to promise delivery and give adequate time to process, I'm seeing it hover around 1.8. See math below, but overall I'm seeing both the filters seemingly "lead" the signal which I wouldn't normally expect.

Assuming prefect kinematics, v_f = v_i + a * t. For the first part of this test we apply a 1 m/s2 acceleration over 1 second from stop. That would give us a 1m/s v_f. In reality I see something near 1m/s on occasion but its usually around 1.14m/s. And that's with some dropped messages, which frankly baffles me with constant acceleration being published faster than filter update rate. Either way, the test for the speed:

Passes without an issue, 1, 1.14, all good. Now the next step is where we see the problem. Going back to our kinematics: dx = v_o * t + 0.5 * a * t * t. If we have our initial velocity at 1 m/s and 0 m/s2 acceleration, we should move forward 1m. Knowing dx = (dv/2) * t, we know that the first step's change in pose was 0.5m. So that's 1.5m, in theory. So... why was the test for
? Because a filter lags the signal. Makes sense.

So what we're actually seeing, with those numbers, is 1.14m/s which gives us a displacement in the 0m/s2 acceleration step of 1.14m. Knowing the start and end velocity of the acceleration phase, we get 0.57 as our displacement, totalling to 1.71m displacement. Which is
than what I'm seeing at 1.8m but its in the
error tolerance the test started within.
So that indicates to me that its leading the signal (?) which is odd. So overall for this particular test, I don't really understand where
came from, I think it should be
in a perfect world and the
tolerance band would still cover
from
as the setpoint if we're accurately tracking our signal. I don't know why we're leading the signal, but again if we had set
as our setpoint,
would fall in the tolerance band.
Given that I see this identically in both the EKF and the UKF this gives me a big "phew" feeling that I don't have to look at transfer functions,
. However its consistent.

and lets us manually fire the callbacks. That would make everything a little more deterministic. But that's outside scope here. I just want to make sure that nothing was broken between ROS1 and ROS2.
Reading over this old code is humbling. There are a lot of things I'd do (very) differently now. :)
Does ROS2 have the ability to wait until all the connections have been established before commencing playback?

I could do something like that, I did a rough test adding sleeps after the node was created to let everything settle down, but it ended up messing up the filter more. That's certainly a "future work" thing to have a single node given to tests vs creating their own, and creating subscribers / publishers / service clients on the fly constantly, that's got to take a toll.

The IMU test changes are a little suspicious. Perhaps we'll need to enable debug mode, comment out all the other tests, and run it, and then repeat with the ROS1 versions, just to see what shakes out.
I'm not, not suspicious of it either, one reason I highlight it.
But that's outside scope here.
Agreed. They pass, they pass, but I also like keeping the server separated for my personal testing style. I like to poke the bear as the bear is seen in the wild.

On the test side of this PR: I'd say there's certainly lots of room for improvement, but the goal here was really to clean up RL functional code, and the changes I made to the tests were singularly with the goal of showing that the functional code changes I made didnt break anything. Test refactoring is out of scope for my attempt of this PR. Though the IMU accelerometer test is showing some confusing results that probably need more investigation. However I'm pretty confident in saying nothing in my refactor caused that so its a feature of the ROS2 port to begin with.
Colcon test now works (except for bags, I know I keep saying I'm not going to do something, then I do it,  but I'm
not going to do the bag file ones, also commented out so it doesnt run default). CI will wait until we're ready to release so we can make use of the ROS PR builder
On my venture debugging I think I can see maybe how the 1.2 -> 1.8 fixes things. See
and
that may potentially be causing a problem. There are 3 places (2 things) that are removed from the code. I don't think they cause this problem since we still query
param on the callback trigger and throw out anything stamped as old, though obviously clearing the queue would be more ideal.
I do notice however that when I run the test by itself, it passes with

. Maybe something is wrong with the resetting, acceleration, or IMU callbacks? If I move it to the first test, it passes but then the second test fails. If I mess with some params there, I can get all the tests to pass. That leads me to believe that the state on
isn't being fully reset.
Also after getting everything running and playing nice, I was able to remove all the 10% margins. So that's no longer something to think about
This is definitely something that should be looked at. I'm not sure I'd block this PR for that however -- I just tested against current
which fails every test so its definitely an improvement. I opened
on this IMUAccel test that we had to change to 1.8m when running after other tests.
any thoughts on this?
Haven't gotten to this, I'll take a look tonight :)
- Are there items still to complete for a "complete" Dashing port after this MR? I'd be happy to help with them (yes, including linting).
2 things I know are still missing:
Mabel mentioned on the ROS2 port ticket she’s been delayed in cherry picking all the recent commits in RL from ROS1 that have happened over the last couple years so there’s some there too.

Cool, thanks. I can try adding the CI for it. It looks like there isn't any for ROS1 either, is that the case? If so, I would be willing to set it up with CircleCI, but I would need to be added to the managing group on Github.
Mhm, that does appear to be the case.
Looks like I don’t have admin to enable it. I was also planning on setting up the ROS build farm PR builder for CI when I released dashing and eloquent on their devel branches.
We should continue this in the ros2 port ticket
Went through everything, looks awesome! I like the new changes and making the ros filter templated! I didn't see anything, had some very minor comments/questions.
My IMU is unfortunately broken :/ so I don't have the ability to test this until I get a new one.
I like the new changes and making the ros filter templated!

This was actually the way it was originally written, but for one reason or another I convinced myself that it wasn't the right approach, so I changed it for ROS2. Happy for the templates to return, though. I'm not that fussed either way.
Is there anything else we want to sort out before we merge this?
I convinced myself that it wasn't the right approach

I think its as good as anything. I think the power of templates is better displayed when there are many, many implementations and needs. Something with 20 implementations the "if/else" on a parameter string gets exhaustive. Pluginlib is good for something like this as well but frankly it didn't come to mind at the time. Templates make it easier to have a bunch of code run and make different executable for each but reduce code redundancy to near-zero. I didn't know it was intentional to remove the templates and create 1 executable for all the filters. I probably wouldn't have done it if I knew that's what you were going for. I thought of R_L in terms of
node and
node, but I suppose I could also get behind a single node with a parameter on each. I haven't gone through the forks recently, has anyone implemented another filter that could be added upstream?
I don't think there's anything I think I need to do before merging. I was hoping for someone independently to give it a whirl and report back, but I think its ready to go.
LGTM. Did not test on-vehicle but the code looks sound.
Thanks for all the effort!

pr_details_more: 12 is the maximum number of new objects at stow task of ARC2017.
In stow task, we have 24 objects, and weight scale context works for 3 / 12 in worst case. So I simulated at the worst case 6 = (3 / 12) * 24.

pr_code:
(setq obj (make-cube 100 100 100))
(setq obj-2 (make-cube 100 100 100))
(send obj :assoc obj-2)
(send obj :locate #f(123 123 123))
(objects (list obj obj-2))
(print (send obj :worldpos))
(print (send obj :vertices))
(print (send obj-2 :worldpos))
(print (send obj-2 :vertices))
(if nil
    (progn
      (send obj :move-to (make-coords)) ;; ng                                   
      (send obj :worldcoords)
      )
  (progn
    (send obj :reset-coords) ;; ok                                              
    ))
(print "--")
(print (send obj :worldpos))
(print (send obj :vertices))
(print (send obj-2 :worldpos))
(print (send obj-2 :vertices))

(setq obj (make-cube 100 100 100))
(setq obj-2 (make-cube 100 100 100))
(send obj :assoc obj-2)
(send obj :locate #f(123 123 123))
(objects (list obj obj-2))
(print (send obj :vertices))
(print (send obj-2 :vertices))
(if nil
    (progn
      (send obj :move-to (make-coords)) ;; ng                                   
      (send obj :worldcoords)
      )
  (progn
    (send obj :reset-coords) ;; ok                                              
    ))
(print "--")
(print (send obj :vertices))
(print (send obj-2 :vertices))

(let (c2 c2 obj cds)
  (setq c1 (make-cube 100 100 100))
  (send c1 :set-color :red)
  (setq c2 (make-cylinder 30 100))
  (send c2 :set-color :green)
  (send c1 :assoc c2)
  (setq obj (instance bodyset :init (make-cascoords)
                      :bodies (list c1 c2)))
  (send obj :locate #f(123 123 123))
  (setq cds (send obj :copy-coords))
  (format t "(send obj :locate #f(123 123 123))~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices))
  (send obj :worldcoords)
  (format t "(send obj :worldcoords)~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices))
  (send obj :reset-coords)
  (format t "(send obj :reset-coords)~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices))
  (send obj :worldcoords)
  (format t "(send obj :worldcoords)~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices))
  (send obj :transform cds)
  (format t "(send obj :transform cds)~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices))
  (send obj :worldcoords)
  (format t "(send obj :worldcoords)~%")
  (print (send-all (send (body-to-faces obj) :faces) :vertices)))

  - title: "Linear Acceleration"

    field: [linear_acceleration/x, linear_acceleration/y, linear_acceleration/z]
global:
  layout: vertical
  legend_font_size: 20
  label_font_size: 20
  title_font_size: 20
  
plots:

    topic: [/imu/data_raw, /imu/data_raw, /imu/data_raw]
    field: [angular_velocity/x, angular_velocity/y, angular_velocity/z]
    color: [red, green, yellow]
  - title: "Linear Acceleration"

    color: [yellow, cyan, magenta]

"label_font_size" and "title_font_size" global options to specify the font size of all subplot

pr_contents: Implements interaction between the Stop Primitive and Grsim
Added motion controller commands for Stop Primitive in grsim_command_primitive_visitor.cpp.
Added stopping at the robots current position and orientation, no option for coasting to a stop yet
Manually tested if the robot stops in Grsim with a simple chron timer in main.cpp:
N/A
I'm having a little trouble thinking of how to add the option to coast to a stop and what that would look like for a MotionControllerCommand
Hmm. This is a tricky problem, because we control the velocity of the robot directly. I'll defer to
with regards to how neccesary modeling coasting to a stop is, but if it's not super important then I think that it's probably more effort then it's worth.
It's worth noting that we're at least on par with the old code though. Just dug around a bit and found the equivalent snippet from the old codebase:
LOL the old code was janky.
The exact behavior of coasting during Stop is really not a big concern, especially in grsim. There's not really cases where we
want to pick coasting vs not coasting in most realistic scenarios I can think of. Right now I think it's more effort than it's worth, so just giving the same behavior regardless of the
boolean is totally fine, just leave a comment in the
function explaining that is intentional.
I added the comment, but is there a way in high level to stop providing power to the robots wheels?
No, our High Level / Gameplay logic doesn't control wheel power directly. That's why we abstract things with the Primitives.

There's no way to stop providing power to the robot wheels in grSim because we are only able to directly control the robot's velocity. There's no concept of "wheel power" like how you would expect in real life.
I believe our real robots do simply stop providing power to the wheels when coasting to a stop in real life, but we unfortunately can't perfectly replicate that with grSim.
oh ok
Is there anything else that needs to be done with this pull request?

function in the
class throwing exceptions has been temporarily fixed in
. Make sure to update your branch.

Please merge when you get the chance

Seems to work fine for me after a day of testing dropping network and putting back on in VM.
Existing Tests are fine too.
We might want to reduce the watcher gone timeout. Not sure what is the point of keeping a flip, that we know has been disconnected already...
Changelog :
[rocon_gateway] not removing flips on shutdown to have similar behavior
[rocon_gateway] deleting old flips when flipping again, in case.
[rocon_gateway] not unregistering gateway on shutdown to have similar behavior if error
[rocon_hub] simplify gateway unavailable/dead to have only one state "gone"
[rocon_hub_client] small fix to trigger update and exit quickly on shutdown
Only one small thing : the existing "flips" from the origin gateway are still duplicated in Redis, but it doesn't seem to have any harmful effect from what I could observe.
The behavior when dropping that gateway after long time absent (timeout 300) doesn't seem to be correct.
This usually happens :
More fixes have gone in, most notably some redesign to make sure the gateway rewrite it s data into redis if the hub eventually decides to drop it.

When I have multiple mechanical units in a system then I usually append the unit names as a prefix.
For example using "ROB_X" like this: ROB_1_signal_name, ROB_2_signal_name, etc...

I would also choose to create a RobotWare Add-In that inspects the robot system during installation, and automatically loads the necessary configurations and RAPID modules. However, this would probably require quite a bit of effort if you are not familiar with creating such Add-Ins.

The "Assigned to Device" field is only required when connecting the signal to a physical IO-device. When the field is left empty, then the signal will only be virtual. So it will not be of any help here.

So voltage information added in this PR is just for debugging.

pr_title: Fix CI pipeline by controlling fail-on-build
pr_contents: Presently the CI is deadlocked given the build for master branch is currently broken. This prevents our CI pipeline from completing and pushing updated docker images to our automated docker repo, thus blocking the use of CI for testing PR that could be merged to fix the build for master.

This PR simply adds a build ARG that controls the fail-on-build behavior that allows the docker build to succeed even if the colcon build for the repo fails (default), thus keeping sure the CI images remain fresh.
Alternatively, we could just skip the colcon build step entirely for the tag
, given the build artifacts for workspace are wiped clean when used in CI anyhow.
Minor nitpick - I would have probably made the variable name "IGNORE_BUILD_FAILURE" as that seems more clear to me. But this is fine. I'd like Carl to approve before we merge.
So something like this?

Given the connotation of the variable name, it seem like it would demand a default value to be set to something, yet booleans as environment variables is a bit unconstrained, so I instead opted for just set or unset, with the name worded so default could be left unset.
Feel free to replace this with a more idiomatic shell style.

If I understand correctly, if someone knows that the Dockerhub build is failing and a PR is intended to fix that, they'd set this flag in the PR so it automatically passes and gets the green check mark? Why not just merge the fix with the red X, which would fix master and dockerhub, and other PRs would start to pass again?
If I understand correctly, I'd rather just do the latter and leave this PR out.
they'd set this flag in the PR so it automatically passes and gets the green check mark?

I'm not sure how you'd go about that presently. If you want to convey any configuration information to the CI, that usually entails commuting changes into the configuration, presumably not what you'd eventually want to merge to master with the PR though. There may be some ways for submitter to annotate a PR via GitHub comments or git commit messages to effect workflow, but its not commonly among CI providers:
Why not just merge the fix with the red X, which would fix master and docker hub, and other PRs would start to pass again?

That's is one approach; just verify fixing PR offline. Still, this would leave CI for all other PRs from master blocked until such a fix is eventually merged. Looking back, nor would it be obvious which merged PR restored a passing CI, as it too would still be marked as failing.

I think it might be a question of priority; hosting complete yet stale builds of nav2 vs. fresh yet potentially unfinished builds on docker hub. This might fair case to skip colcon build step when building from Dockerhub, so we just don't have to worry about this again. How about this?
Still, this would leave CI for all other PRs from master blocked until such a fix is eventually merged.

We've just been merging them regardless because we can see from CI that the failure is a known issue. By just marking the PR as passed by setting a flag in CI, even though it is really failing to build doesn't seem useful to me. I'd rather have that big red X staring me in the face saying "Fix me!" :-)
Looking back, nor would it be obvious which merged PR restored a passing CI, as it too would still be marked as failing.
I'm not sure I see how this solves that problem. Basically, the build starts to pass once the CI flag is set, independent of any particular PR.
I guess, what I'm saying is, there's nothing wrong with the PR per se, but I don't see me ever wanting to use it.

I think you initially raised the issue. Do you prefer to have a knob to turn to just mark the build as passed, regardless of actual build status? I'm guessing this is not exactly what you had in mind, either.
- I discussed with
and I agree that this isn't necessary since we can just merge PRs to fix the build. Thanks anyway but we're not going to accept this change.
pr_quotes: they'd set this flag in the PR so it automatically passes and gets the green check mark?
Why not just merge the fix with the red X, which would fix master and docker hub, and other PRs would start to pass again?
Still, this would leave CI for all other PRs from master blocked until such a fix is eventually merged.
Looking back, nor would it be obvious which merged PR restored a passing CI, as it too would still be marked as failing.

pr_title: A new Navigation 2 Tutorial for Turtlebot3
pr_contents: Merging
into
will
coverage by
The diff coverage is
Powered by
. Last update
. Read the
So I love that this exists!

However I don't think this is the right place for it. The first half reads like a really greta blog post, and the second half is more tools and 'how to' for Navigation2 rather than anything specific for the turtlebot, so here's my proposal: this should be broken into a set of Wiki pages in GitHub to maximize utility and reusability. This way we can also modify these as it changes without having to deal with PRs.
The way I think this should be broken into Wiki Articles:

I think the Hardware/OS section doesn't need to exist. This should be supportive of windows/MacOS and it might make people think that they require to use this hardware (or something this powerful) to use navigation, which would be an expensive implication for students/hobbyists

The install for ROS2 page should just be a hyperlink to the actual ROS2 install instructions. Statically typing them here is just asking for future-maintenance vs just saying look at this open robotics maintained page with current instructions. Remove the test ROS2 section, that should be a hyperlink to a open robotics "tutorials" page for the same reasons. Maintenance of this type of documentation is crucial and those pages we probably won't look at after publication since the maintainers are knowledgeable enough to not need that set so they'll fall out of date quickly.
So I love that this exists!

However I don't think this is the right place for it. The first half reads like a really greta blog post, and the second half is more tools and 'how to' for Navigation2 rather than anything specific for the turtlebot, so here's my proposal: this should be broken into a set of Wiki pages in GitHub to maximize utility and reusability. This way we can also modify these as it changes without having to deal with PRs.
The way I think this should be broken into Wiki Articles:

I think the Hardware/OS section doesn't need to exist. This should be supportive of windows/MacOS and it might make people think that they require to use this hardware (or something this powerful) to use navigation, which would be an expensive implication for students/hobbyists

The install for ROS2 page should just be a hyperlink to the actual ROS2 install instructions. Statically typing them here is just asking for future-maintenance vs just saying look at this open robotics maintained page with current instructions. Remove the test ROS2 section, that should be a hyperlink to a open robotics "tutorials" page for the same reasons. Maintenance of this type of documentation is crucial and those pages we probably won't look at after publication since the maintainers are knowledgeable enough to not need that set so they'll fall out of date quickly.

Thanks for your feedback. We finally had some time to talk about documentation this week. We consider using one of the popular documentation tool options such as Github wiki, Github Pages, Readme files, Read the Doc etc. We haven't decided which one to use yet :) I created a wiki page for this tutorial. You can find the link below. In my opinion it looks more organized and maintainable. I will add hyperlinks to ROS2, Gazebo, and Turtlebot installation pages. I agree it is more maintainable that way.

is looking into the Github pages option. We talked about what the main structure of the documentation should look like. I will share it here to get everyone's feedback. Once we decide what to use for documentation, this tutorial will be separated into several different pages and some sections will be linked to other websites such as ROS2 installation and Turtlebot setup.

I agree with you System Requirements title is wrong and misleading. I will change the system requirements to Tested Systems. I think it is important that we share the systems that we use for testing the stack until we know it works on majority of computers in the market. I will add more systems to the list.

PS: When I created this tutorial, I didn't plan it as a main how to use the navigation2 stack tutorial. I wanted it to be a single page tutorial that covers everything from setting up the operating system to getting the system up an running, so for example a professor who wants to use it as a class project can easily use it with a little bit of modification or ROS newbies can easily complete this tutorial with almost no prior experience in ROS. I would say this is more like a book chapter, so it can be printed or used as a handout in a workshop. I don't think advanced users will need a very detailed tutorial. I will create a much simpler tutorial to test the stack.
Ok, sounds good. I think GitHub wiki is a good place for the moment since there's no easily accessible ROS2 wiki. That wiki looks good, I'd just ship it to the navigation2 wiki.
We finally had some time to talk about documentation this week.
This is concerning - these discussions should be happening in the open. I know its not about this PR, but

this is looking alot like the early few months of Navigation2 where the you all at Intel make a decision behind closed doors that the rest of us have to live with it. These things should be in tickets, discourse, etc for both active discussion from all participants and at the very least documentation people can later reference.

I feel like I am being misunderstood and also you pulled the trigger a little bit too fast :) I am sure the documentation will be discussed during the working group meeting this Thursday. There is no decision that has already been made. Currently, different documentation tool options are being tested and all we have is a simple documentation structure. I will submit an issue about it soon. We definitely need more community input , that is why there will be many open issues and working group discussions etc for documentation.
This is concerning - these discussions should be happening in the open
Here's a quick summary of the discussion.

We considered the wiki for documentation. It has nice features like search and navigation bars. However, it lacks the ability for outside users to submit PRs. We either allow anyone to edit it freely or lock it down so only we can edit it. Also, the working group had recommended not using it in the past. They suggested either "github pages" or "read the docs". We noticed OSRF had gone to "github pages".
We figured "github pages" was probably the 'right' thing to do, and I agreed to go play with it to see what it would take.

My take on github pages is that they are the right thing in the long run. They are flexible, can be made dynamic through javascript, could be customised with lots of preprocessing steps, etc. But in the short run, they are going to have a learning curve and take effort that I just don't want to invest right now.
My recommendation is to just stick with the wiki until the pain of maintaining it outweighs the pain of setting up github pages :-)

I agree. The github wiki is a good location for now locked to contributors. Once things stabilize and/or someone has a burst of interest to migrate to ReadTheDocs or similar, thats a good place to live but alot of overhead for the time being.
I would just like to make sure these discussions are happening in text - or summaries of them in text - in github or elsewhere that is searchable and able to be referenced.

(Another of my on-going wars on transparency) the open development of much of the ROS ecosystem is one of the ways that makes it easy to learn and understand the “why is it this way” for future folks to improve or understand the deficiencies.

I jump on these things quickly to try to reinforce good habits. At the end of the day Intel and Samsung aren’t the main “customers” of this work and it would be a terrible waste of our time if we put in all this work and then its never used because its sorely lacking in context, which happens quite alot in my experience looking at failed open source projects.
Anyhow, thats here nor there for this PR. What’s the plan? Merge this, wiki, or both?
